In the previous verse, it was explained that there was a close relationship between the two great families, the family of Ibrahim and the family of Imran. In this verse, the story of one of their prominent descendants is explained, namely the wife of Imran who was pregnant. She vowed that the child in her womb would be dedicated as a servant who would always serve and worship in Baitulmakdis (Jerusalem). She would not burden her child later, because the child had been purely dedicated to serve there.

At the end of verse 34, it was explained that Allah heard what Imran's wife said, knew her pure intention, and heard her praise to Allah when she made a private prayer. These are the things that caused her prayer to be answered, and her hope to be fulfilled as a gift and kindness from Allah.

In these few verses, the name Imran is mentioned twice. The first is in verse 33, which is Imran, the father of Prophet Musa (Moses), peace be upon him; while the second is in verse 35, which is Imran, the father of Maryam (Mary). The time span between these two people is very long. This verse shows that a mother is allowed to make a vow regarding her child, and is allowed to benefit from her child for herself. In this verse, there is also a lesson, namely that we should pray to Allah that our children become people who are diligent in worship and useful for their religion, like the prayer of Prophet Zakaria (Zechariah) which is narrated in the Al-Qur'an.

After Imran's wife gave birth, and it turned out that the child born was a girl when she had hoped for a boy, sadness appeared on her face and her hope to fulfill her vow was cut off. She said, "My Lord, I have given birth to a female." As if she was asking forgiveness from God, that the girl was not worthy to fulfill her vow, namely to serve in Baitulmakdis. But Allah knows better the status of the baby girl who was born, in fact she is far better than the baby boy she asked for.
text.36:
This verse affirms the nobility of a daughter who is born, and rejects the presumption that a female infant is of lower dignity than a male infant, as expected by Imran's wife.

After Imran's wife realized that her child was a girl, and believed in the wisdom and secrets behind this reality, she declared that the baby would be named Maryam. She would not retract what she had vowed, which was to dedicate her child to serve in the Baitulmakdis, even though the baby was a girl and, in her opinion, not suitable to guard the Baitulmakdis. However, she would be a devout servant of God. Imran's wife prayed that Allah would guard and protect her baby from the temptations of Satan that might distance her from virtue. Regarding this, the Prophet Muhammad (saw) said the following:

"Every descendant of Adam is touched by Satan at the time of his birth except Maryam and her son." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Hurairah).
text.37:
Allah accepted Maryam as a vow due to her mother's supplication. Allah was pleased for her to be solely devoted to worship and service in the Baitulmakdis (Temple in Jerusalem), even though Maryam was still young and only a girl. Whereas, those who were specifically dedicated to serving in the Baitulmakdis were usually men who were mature and capable of performing the service. Allah also protected and educated her, and raised her in the best possible way.

The education that Allah gave to Maryam encompassed both spiritual and physical education. Thus, she became a person with a healthy and strong body, as well as good character, pure in both spirit and body. Allah also appointed Prophet Zakaria as her guardian and protector.

It is narrated that her mother picked her up and took her to the mosque, then placed her in front of the rabbis who were there. She said, "Take this child whom I have vowed." So they competed with each other for the baby, because she was the daughter of their leader. Each of them wanted to be her guardian. Prophet Zakaria then said, "I am more entitled to be her guardian, because her aunt is my wife." But they refused unless it was determined by lot. So they went to the Jordan River, releasing their arrows into the river, with the intention that whoever's arrow could withstand the river's current and rise quickly, then he would be entitled to be Maryam's guardian. It turned out that Prophet Zakaria's arrow was the one that could withstand and float on the surface of the water, while the other arrows were swept away and sank. So in that lottery, Prophet Zakaria won, and Maryam was immediately handed over to him to be cared for and educated under the care of her own aunt.

When Maryam began to mature, she began to worship in the mihrab (prayer niche). Every time Prophet Zakaria entered the mihrab, he found there food and various fruits that were not available at that time because it was not their season. Zakaria once asked Maryam about the fruits, where she got them from, even though it was the dry season. So Maryam replied, "It is from Allah. Indeed, Allah provides sustenance to whom He wills without account."

This story is presented to affirm the prophethood of Muhammad saw, and to divert the minds of the People of the Book who limit the bounty of prophethood to the descendants of Bani Israil (Children of Israel) only. It is also to correct the opinion of the Arab polytheists who reject the prophethood of Muhammad saw because they consider him only a human being like them.

Allah has made Adam a chosen one and a caliph on earth, and made Nuh a chosen one and the second father of mankind, and then chose Ibrahim and his family to be chosen people and guides for mankind. The Arabs and the People of the Book know this, but the Arab polytheists boast of being descendants of Ismail and followers of the religion of Ibrahim, and the People of the Book boast of the election of the family of Imran from the descendants of Bani Israil, the grandson of Prophet Ibrahim. Many Arabs and People of the Book know that Allah has chosen them solely by His will, as a bounty and grace from Him. So what prevents Allah from making Muhammad a chosen one on this earth, just as Allah chose them as well? Allah chooses whomever He wills among His creation. Allah has chosen Muhammad saw and made him a leader for mankind and brought them out of the darkness of shirk (polytheism) and ignorance, into the light of truth and faith. No one from the family of Ibrahim and Imran has a greater influence than Muhammad saw.
text.38:
In the previous verse, the story of the family of Imran was narrated. In this verse, the story surrounding the family of Zakaria is presented, highlighting the very close relationship between the two, in order to emphasize the virtue of the family of Imran. When Zakaria saw the glory and high status that Maryam held before Allah, he felt a desire to have a child similar to Maryam in intelligence and nobility in the sight of Allah.

Although Zakaria knew that his wife was a barren woman and already old, he still hoped for a gift from Allah. In the mihrab where Maryam worshipped, Zakaria offered a prayer to Allah, hoping that He would be pleased to grant him a righteous descendant, obedient and devoted to Allah. A prayer that arose from the depths of a sincere heart and full of trust in the compassion of Allah, the All-Hearing and the One who answers all prayers, was immediately granted by Allah.
text.39:
While Zechariah was still standing in the mihrab, and had just finished praying, the Angel Gabriel came to him informing him that Allah would bestow upon him a son named Yahya.

Yahya would later confirm the prophet created by Allah, who was born unlike other babies, through a mother but without a father, namely Prophet Isa. Yahya is a prophet who leads his people towards glory and happiness. A prophet who distances himself from lust and desire, solely to devote himself to Allah. He is a prophet born from a noble lineage, namely the prophets salawatullahi 'alaihim.

It is narrated that when Prophet Yahya was still a child, he once walked past children who were playing. They invited him to play. He said, "I was not created to play."
text.40: After Zechariah was certain of the truth of the good news, he began to feel astonished at the possibility of a child being born to him in his old age. Words slipped from his tongue, "My Lord, how can I have a son when I am already old and my wife is barren?" Allah said, and His word was conveyed by the angel, "Thus does Allah do what He wills. When Allah wills something, He creates the cause for it or He creates it without going through the usual causes. Nothing happens without His will. All matters lie within His power. It is not appropriate to question how Allah creates it, because the human mind will not be able to know it."
text.41:
After Zechariah heard that answer from the Angel Gabriel, he said, "My Lord, grant me a sign that my wife will conceive."

According to al-Hasan al-Basri, Prophet Zechariah asked this in order to immediately obtain joy in his heart or to welcome the blessing with gratitude, without waiting until the child was born.

Then Allah explained that the sign that his wife was pregnant was that he himself would not speak to other people for three days, except by using hand gestures, head movements, and so on, and that he should remember and glorify Allah. Allah commanded Zechariah not to speak for three days, so that all his time would be used for remembrance and glorification of Him, as a true expression of gratitude.

According to al-Qurtubi, some commentators (mufasir) say that Zechariah's three days of muteness was as a punishment from Allah for asking the angel for a sign after their conversation.

At the end of this verse, Allah commands Zechariah to constantly remember Allah and to remember Him as much as possible in the morning and evening, as a sign of gratitude to Him.
text.42:
This verse returns to the story of the family of Imran, after the previous verse recounted the affairs of the family of Zakaria, who were also part of the family of Imran. In this verse, Allah reminds Prophet Muhammad saw, about the events experienced by Maryam when she was visited by the Angel Jibril (Maryam/19: 19-21). Jibril's conversation with Maryam here is not like Jibril's conversations with the prophets, which were the conveyance of Allah's revelation to them, but rather as a conversation between an angel and Allah's saints (wali), which takes the form of inspiration (ilham).

Maryam's expression of gratitude to Allah through worship and unwavering obedience further preserved the glory and perfection of her personality, and kept her far from all undesirable traits. Therefore, it is natural that Maryam received inspiration (ilham) from Allah through Jibril as a tribute to her.

Jibril emphasized that Allah had chosen Maryam to serve in the Baitulmakdis, and purified her from outward and inward defects, and destined her to give birth to a prophet even though she had never been touched by a man. Allah distinguished Maryam above all women of her time. The Prophet saw said:

"The best women in the world are four: Maryam binti Imran, Asiyah the wife of Pharaoh, Khadijah binti Khuwailid and Fatimah binti Muhammad." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Hisyam bin Hakim)
text.43:
Allah obligated Maryam to obey Him as a sign of gratitude for the blessings He bestowed upon her, with His saying which means, "O Maryam, be devoutly obedient to your Lord and prostrate and bow with those who bow [in prayer]." (Quran 3:43). What is meant by "prostrate" here is prostration like the prostration in prayer, and what is meant by "bow" is the prayer itself. This verse commands Maryam to perform congregational prayer together with others.

Prayer according to the understanding of the Jews at that time was: prayer or prostration. Prostration by placing the forehead on the ground or the floor was their prayer, and all the worship that Maryam performed took place in the mihrab.
text.44:
This verse concludes by directing the conversation to Prophet Muhammad, stating that the story is among the stories he did not know, while it is in accordance with the content of the Torah.

Allah states in this verse that what has been narrated, namely the story of Maryam and Zakaria, are stories that were never witnessed by Prophet Muhammad saw, or his family, nor did Muhammad ever read them in a book, nor were they taught by a teacher. That is the revelation, which Allah sent down to him through Ruhul-Amin, to be evidence of the truth of his prophethood, and to refute the hujjah (arguments) of those who deny it.

Then Allah also states that Prophet Muhammad was not yet present and certainly did not witness them when they held a lottery between Zakaria and them, to determine who would care for Maryam.

Prophet Muhammad saw was not present in their dispute to care for Maryam. They were forced to hold a lottery to resolve the dispute. Those who disputed were prominent people, namely their priests. The dispute was solely driven by a great desire to care for and nurture Maryam. Perhaps this desire was because her father, Imran, was their leader, so they hoped to receive blessings from the task of caring for Maryam. It may also be because they knew in the religious books that a great event would happen to Maryam and her son. Or perhaps it was because they believed that caring for the baby girl was a religious obligation, because the baby was vowed to serve in the Baitulmakdis.

This verse is placed after explaining the story of Maryam, to explain that Prophet Muhammad never read the story of the Imran family (Bani Israil), because he was an ummi (unlettered). Moreover, he never heard it from anyone because he also lived at that time among people who were ummi.

There is no way for the Prophet to know the ins and outs of this story except by witnessing it with his own eyes, or by way of revelation. Witnessing with his own eyes is impossible, because the event occurred in the era before the birth of Prophet Muhammad saw. If so, then Prophet Muhammad knew it by way of revelation.

The People of the Book who deny the Al-Qur'an say that the contents of the Al-Qur'an that are in accordance with the contents of their Book are from their book, while those that contradict the contents of their book they say are not true. The contents of the Al-Qur'an that are not found in their Book are also considered untrue. This attitude is only because of their arrogance and hostility.

Muslims believe that everything explained in the Al-Qur'an is true. Because there are sufficient arguments to prove that Muhammad saw is a prophet. Al-Qur'an verses that contradict previous books are seen as corrections to errors found in those books, because they have been altered or are no longer in accordance with the benefit of the ummah.
text.45:
In this verse, Allah reminds Prophet Muhammad of the story of Maryam when Jibril came to her, bringing her the good news that she would give birth to a righteous son. When Jibril delivered this good news, Allah had chosen her, sanctified her to continue worshipping Allah, and to always be grateful to Him. The angel referred to here is Jibril, as in Allah's saying:

"…then We sent to her Our Spirit (Jibril), and he appeared before her in the form of a perfect man." (Maryam/19: 17).

Isa is called "the word of Allah," as a notification about the process of his creation, which is different from the creation of ordinary humans. Isa a.s. is named al-Masih, and Al-Masih is a royal title, because the word Al-Masih in the Torah and the Gospel means "the anointed one." Anointing was a custom in their traditions, that whoever had been anointed with holy oil by the head of the religion, then he had become holy, capable of holding the kingdom, possessing knowledge and power, and receiving blessings. Here, Allah shows that Isa always received blessings even though he had never been anointed with holy oil.

Some also say that the name Isa comes from the Greek word "yasu," meaning "the saved, the chosen one." The prophets of the past had explained that an al-Masih would come, a king who would restore the lost power of the Children of Israel.

So when Isa was born and named al-Masih, a group of them believed in him. The Jews who denied him argued that the promised one had not yet come. He is called Ibnu Maryam (son of Maryam) to give the understanding that Isa was born without a father, which is why he is attributed to his mother.

Isa a.s. has a prominent position in the world, because he has a place in the hearts of the believers and is respected. The improvements left by Isa remain imprinted in later days. His greatness is far more real than the greatness of rulers or kings, because people respect rulers and kings to avoid their torture, out of fear of their injustice, or to curry favor in order to be given worldly positions. Such greatness is merely superficial splendor, without any trace in the soul, and may even cause hatred.

In addition to that, Isa has greatness in the Hereafter, namely a high position and glory, because he is always close to Allah.
text.46:
Isa spoke to people when he was a child in his cradle to explain his mother's purity from the accusations thrown at her, and to be proof of his prophethood. Isa also spoke to people when he was an adult, that is, after Allah raised him to be a messenger and revealed revelation to him, to convey His commands and prohibitions to mankind.

He is included among the righteous people who have been given blessings by Allah, namely the prophets, the *siddiqin*, and the *syuhada'*.
text.47:
Maryam directed her words to Allah, who had sent Jibril, saying, "How can I have a son when no man has touched me? Will such a thing happen through marriage, or is it solely by the power of Allah?" Perhaps Maryam's words were to express her amazement at Allah's power and to regard it as a great miracle. Allah explained that such a birth would occur when Allah willed it; Allah creates what He wills. If Allah wills to decree something, He only needs to say to it, "Be," and it is.

Allah creates whatever He wills, including creating wondrous things that deviate from the norm, such as creating a child without a father. Even Prophet Adam was created without a father or mother.

The verse above inspires humans to learn, seek knowledge, and conduct research, but the results or outputs of research cannot always be applied or used. This depends on a study based on the principle of benefit for humans and not contradicting the values and laws in the Islamic religion. As long as it does not contradict Islamic law, the results of research can be used or applied in society. Genetics, for example, like other branches of science, is encouraged by Islam to be studied in depth. However, if there is a part of the research that leads to a violation of Islamic law, its application must be reconsidered.

The same applies to genetics. If the direction of a research has entered a "sensitive" area, it is best to conduct an evaluation to make a decision to continue or stop it, or to divert the direction of the research towards one that is more conducive to the realization of human welfare.

Perceptions about cloning vary. Cloning is not creation. If viewed carefully, what is done in cloning is only destroying the nucleus of an egg cell and replacing it with the nucleus of a donor individual. The cell nucleus can be taken from somatic cells, and does not have to be from reproductive cells. This process will produce offspring that are identical to the donor individual. Everything is done on the same species.

If cloning is seen as a reflection of the Islamic belief regarding "rebirth," then that is not true, because in the verse below it is clear that human "rebirth" is controlled by Allah SWT. Allah says:

"And it is He who begins the creation; then He will repeat it, and that is easier for Him. To Him belongs the loftiest description in the heavens and the earth. And He is the Exalted in Might, the Wise." (ar-Rum/30: 27).

The Islamic view of genetics can be exemplified in the verse below:

"We will show them Our signs in the horizons and within themselves until it becomes clear to them that it is the truth. But is it not sufficient concerning your Lord that He is, over all things, a Witness?" (Fussilat/41: 53)

That verse inspires humans to strive to "read" their own genes. This is in the context of their efforts to recognize themselves and be grateful to Allah SWT. By reading genetic mapping, we will know, among other things, whether or not there are hereditary diseases. Thus, this science will contribute to human health in its efforts to prevent the emergence of certain diseases and how to overcome them.

However, if in the course of revealing knowledge, it then branches out into something that tends to harm humans, then Islam will reject it. Human cloning, for example, Islam firmly rejects. Some things that can be put forward regarding the reasons for Islam's rejection of human cloning include:

1. Humans are created by Allah in their most perfect form, and are higher than other creatures. The verse below says so:

"And We have certainly honored the children of Adam and carried them on the land and sea and provided for them of the good things and preferred them over much of what We have created, with [definite] preference." (al-Isra'/17: 70)

By cloning himself, man has degraded himself before other creatures of Allah. Everything is up to ourselves.

2. Cloning contradicts the diversity of creation. Allah created the universe on the basis of diversity. Meanwhile, human cloning is based on uniformity by duplicating all the characteristics of the human who is the donor. Uniformity, for example in appearance and physique, will greatly interfere with daily life activities. For example, in one class, all the students are the result of cloning from the same individual. If one student makes a mistake, it is very difficult for the teacher to identify which child is wrong, because the appearance and physique of all the students are exactly the same.

3. If human cloning is allowed, how should we regulate family and kinship relations between the cloned individual and the donor individual? Can the two be referred to as siblings, or child-father, or are they both themselves? This situation will be very confusing for everyone. It may even destroy the social order that exists today.

4. Cloning contradicts the pattern of natural law which states that every creation consists of pairs as described in Surah adz-dzariyat/51 verse 49 ("And of all things We created two mates; perhaps you will remember."). Cloning denies this verse, because the baby is not produced from the meeting of sperm and egg. All that is needed in cloning is one person (whether male or female only) as a donor.

5. Emotional connection between parents and children will not occur. Whereas this relationship is very important in shaping the character of the child.

From the short list above, it can be seen that too many natural laws will be violated if human cloning is allowed. There is still much other knowledge that needs to be revealed to support the welfare of human life.

Thus is the depiction of Allah's power and the certainty of His will. The description of the speed with which what Allah wills is realized without time limits and without any causal factors is explained by Allah in His word:

And Our command is but one, like a glance of the eye.

(al-Qamar/54: 50)

What is commanded will surely happen immediately. Such a command is called *perintah takwin*. Those who deny the verses of Allah do not justify Isa being born without a father, because their minds are only limited to ordinary events. They do not realize how this universe came into being, while they do not have any *dalil 'aqli* that makes the occurrence of a child without a father impossible. Every day we witness extraordinary events that are thought to be impossible. Some of them have causes that are already known, and are then called new discoveries. There are also those whose causes are unknown and are then called deviations of nature from its laws.

A believer is convinced that something that happens not according to the usual cause proves the power of Allah and that the causes for something to happen do not always have to be in accordance with the considerations of reason. The current generation has seen and witnessed strange and extraordinary events. If such a thing were seen by people in the past, they would certainly consider it an act of magic, or an act of jinn. They do not try to find reasons in denying an event that they themselves do not know the causes of.

Philosophers and scientists of today establish that it is possible for an animal to be born from something that is not an animal. So if that is the case, if an animal is born from another animal of a different kind, it is very possible and reasonable.
text.48: In this verse, it is explained that Allah taught Isa the knowledge of writing and true science, which motivates a person's will to perform beneficial deeds. Allah also gave him the ability to understand the Torah and all the secrets of its laws. Al-Masih knew all the secrets of the law, and then explained them to his people. Allah also taught Isa a.s. the Gospel that He revealed to him.
text.49:
Allah made Isa (Jesus) a messenger to the Children of Israel. Allah sent Isa to the Children of Israel to tell them that his coming brought several great signs, namely "miracles," to them as a confirmation of his message. These miracles included:

First: Prophet Isa could create something in the shape of a bird from clay, and after he breathed into it, it would become a living bird like a regular bird, with the permission of Allah. In reality, it was Allah who created life in the body of the bird, with His power when Isa breathed into it, to make it a miracle for his prophethood.

It is narrated that when Isa a.s. declared himself a prophet and displayed his miracles, the Children of Israel asked him to make a bat. So he took clay, shaped it into a bat, and breathed into it. The bat then flew into the sky. The bat flew as long as the people could see it, and when it was no longer visible to them, the bat fell to the earth and died. This is very different from the creation of other creatures of Allah. It has become *sunnatullah* (Allah's established way) that the miracles given to His prophets are at the request of their people and make their faith dependent on that miracle. So if Isa's people asked him for such a thing, Allah would grant it.

Second: Isa a.s. could cure blindness and leprosy, even though both diseases were difficult for doctors to treat at that time, even though medicine was advanced in Isa's time.

It has also become *sunnatullah* that the miracles of the prophets are in the form of something very well-known in their time. For example, Musa (Moses) was given a staff that could become a snake and swallow all the snakes of the magicians. The Egyptians at that time were very famous for their skill in magic.

To Isa a.s., Allah gave a miracle of the type of medicine that exceeded the ability of the doctors of that time, even though they already had high expertise. Likewise, to Prophet Muhammad saw, was given the miracle of the Al-Qur'an, because what they boasted about at that time was literature.

Third: He could bring the dead back to life, with the permission of Allah. Many narrations explain that Isa brought the dead back to life. Among them was bringing a girl back to life before she was buried and bringing Ya'azir back to life before his body decomposed. But there is no narration that explains that he brought back to life a corpse that had become bones.

Fourth: Isa a.s. could tell what people ate and what they stored in their homes.

The difference between the unseen news conveyed by Isa a.s. and the news of astrologers and shamans, which is sometimes accurate and sometimes not, is that astrologers and shamans reveal something by paying attention to the causes that enable them to know something. This is not the case with the news conveyed by Prophet Isa and by the prophets and messengers. They do not seek or try to find causes, nor do they commit deception, but are purely notifications conveyed to them by Allah swt.

Such were the miracles of Prophet Isa witnessed by the Children of Israel. Indeed, in those miracles there were guidance for them to justify the apostleship and prophethood of Isa. There are also lessons in those miracles to be thought about and drawn conclusions from, namely that Isa a.s. spoke the truth to them. They also knew that what Isa preached was the true command from Allah swt. If they had justified the verses of Allah, acknowledged His Oneness, and believed in Prophet Musa and the Torah he brought, they would surely have believed in Prophet Isa a.s.
text.50:
Prophet Isa (Jesus) came to the Children of Israel to confirm the Torah that existed among them, acknowledging and strengthening it. Not to replace or invalidate its laws, but rather to lighten some of the laws for its followers, which were previously felt as a very heavy burden for them. Therefore, Isa a.s. said, "And to make lawful to you some of what was forbidden to you," meaning some of the foods that were once forbidden to them due to their oppression and numerous requests. Then, Isa made them lawful again as explained by Allah in the Al-Qur'an.

"Because of the wrongdoing of the Jews, We forbade them good things which were (formerly) lawful to them, and for their hindering many from Allah's Way." (an-Nisa'/4:160).

Among the foods that were made lawful again were: fish, camel meat, fat, and it was also made lawful again to work on the Sabbath. Prophet Isa also clarified issues that were the subject of their disputes, as explained in the Al-Qur'an.

"And in order to make clear to you some of that wherein you differ. So fear Allah and obey me." (az-Zukhruf/43: 63).

Then Prophet Isa repeated the explanation of the previous verse, saying, "I have come to you with a sign from your Lord." These miracles became a witness to the truth of the message he brought, as has been mentioned, namely creating birds, healing blindness from birth and leprosy, bringing the dead to life, and informing about hidden things and so on. Because he came bringing clear miracles, clear verses, he then called upon his people to fear Allah, not to oppose Him, and to obey all that he taught them.
text.51:
This verse explains the words of Prophet Isa (Jesus) to his people, that Allah SWT is their Lord together, who must be worshipped, with the declaration of the Oneness of Allah and the acknowledgement that Allah is the Lord of the universe, therefore worship Him.

This is among the commands of Prophet Isa to his people, so that they have the correct belief, which is Tawhid, always fulfilling all of Allah's commands and avoiding all of His prohibitions, outwardly and inwardly. That is the straight and spacious path outlined by the messengers, namely the path that leads to happiness in this world and the hereafter.
text.52:
In this verse and the following verse, the relationship of Prophet Isa (Jesus), peace be upon him, with his people is explained, as well as what he experienced from them; in the form of obstacles, challenges, violence, and plans to kill him. In addition, Allah also explains the help that has been given to the group of people who acknowledge the Oneness of Allah, as well as His threats conveyed to the disbelievers, and the torment that befell them in this world and the hereafter.

When Isa (Jesus), peace be upon him, was certain that his people, the Children of Israel, remained in disbelief and faced strong rejection from them, even intending to harm him, he asked, "Who are my helpers in the cause of Allah?" Isa (Jesus) truly faced a severe challenge from the Jews, who crowded around him and mocked him. They said, "What did so-and-so eat last night, what did he store in his house for tomorrow morning?" Even though Isa (Jesus), peace be upon him, could answer them, they continued to mock him.

In this story, there is a lesson for Prophet Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, and at the same time, it is a comfort for him. Here it is proven that even though many miracles of the prophets are presented, they do not automatically lead to faith. Faith depends on whether the person being invited is willing to accept it.

At the time of increasing challenges and threats, Isa (Jesus) said to the Hawariyyun, who was willing to surrender his soul to Allah and help His Messenger. The Hawariyyun answered, "We are the helpers of Allah's religion," they provided their energy to strengthen the da'wah (propagation) of the Messenger of Allah and were willing to hold fast to his teachings and abandon the past teachings that were wrong. The help requested by Isa (Jesus), peace be upon him, did not require them to participate in warfare but simply to practice the teachings of the religion and its da'wah.

The Hawariyyun were a group of people among the Children of Israel who believed in Al-Masih (the Messiah), and were willing to help, assist him and follow the light that was revealed to him (As-Saff/61:14). They declared to Isa (Jesus), peace be upon him, that they believed in Allah and asked for testimony that they were those who submit themselves (to Allah). This statement was a factor that brought victory in the face of the opposition of his enemies. They asked to be included among those who acknowledge the Oneness of Allah.
text.53:
After they bore witness to the apostleship of Isa (Jesus), peace be upon him, and bore witness to the power of Allah who commanded them to believe in the Book revealed to him, and to obey all His commands, they said, "Our Lord, we have believed in what You have sent down." This statement is an act of humility towards Allah, and an expression of their state to Allah, after declaring to His messenger to further clarify their stance. "And we have followed the messenger," and obeyed all the commands he brought from Allah.

Placing the word "followed" after the word "believed" in this verse indicates that the faith of the Hawariyyun (disciples of Jesus) had reached a level of certainty, which directed their souls in carrying out every action. True knowledge is knowledge that demands actions in accordance with that knowledge, while knowledge that does not influence actions is vague and deficient knowledge, not providing conviction and tranquility. Many people think that they are knowledgeable, but when they perform an action, it turns out that their actions cannot be controlled and restrained, and only then do they realize that they were wrong in their claim.

After the Hawariyyun declared to Allah their testimony to the truth of the Book and His messenger, they then pleaded to Allah to include them among those who acknowledge the Oneness of Allah (swt).
text.54: After Allah explained about the Hawariyyun, in this verse, Allah explains the attitude of the Children of Israel towards Isa a.s. They devised a plot and intended to destroy him by reporting and slandering Isa to their king. But Allah outwitted and thwarted their plot, and they did not succeed in killing him. Isa a.s. was raised to heaven by Allah and replaced with someone who resembled him, so that people were convinced that the one crucified was Isa a.s. Allah's recompense overcame their deceit and inflicted misery upon those disbelievers, without them expecting it. Allah's plan, unknown to His servants, was actually to establish His sunnah and perfect His wisdom.
text.55:
Allah repaid the deceit of the disbelievers by raising Jesus (peace be upon him) to Him. In this is good news for the Prophet, concerning the coming of Allah's help to save him from the deceit of the disbelievers, so that they would not succeed in their efforts to carry out that deceit.

Allah will raise Prophet Jesus to Him and will cause him to die when his appointed time arrives, after descending from the sky at the appointed time, in accordance with the saying of the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him):

"By Him in Whose Hand is my life, the son of Mary (Jesus) will descend amongst you as a just ruler, he will break the cross, kill the pig, abolish Jizya and the wealth will be in abundance so that nobody will accept it, and one single prostration to Allah (in prayer) will be better than the whole world and whatever is in it." (Narrated by al-Bukhari from Abu Hurairah).

"Allah cleansed Jesus (peace be upon him) from the disbelievers," by saving him from their evil, insults, slander, and accusations, which they would have done, and will make his followers who believe believe that he is a servant of Allah and His messenger, believe in Jesus' words that he was sent to give good news (as-Shaff/61:6) about the coming of a messenger of Allah, who will come after him, whose name is Ahmad (Prophet Muhammad) (as-Shaff/61:6). Allah will raise those who believe to a high degree, unlike the Jews who deceived and denied Prophet Jesus, whose status was lowered by Allah. This high degree is sometimes in the field of faith which is spiritual, and in the field of morals and perfection of etiquette and their closeness to the truth and their distance from falsehood. Sometimes the advantage is worldly, namely that they will hold the reins of leadership in the world.

Then all mankind will be returned to Allah, that is, on the Day of Resurrection, and Allah will decide the matters in which they differed in religious matters, including the disputes that occurred between the followers of Jesus (peace be upon him) and those who did not believe in him.
text.56:
Allah explains that the Jews who deny Prophet Muhammad will be punished with a severe torment both in this world and in the Hereafter.

The worldly punishment that will befall them is that they will be killed and captured, and dominated by other nations. As for the punishment of the Hereafter, it is Allah's severe torment on the Day of Judgment. At that time, they will not receive help from anyone.
text.57:
Allah explains that those who believe and do righteous deeds are those who affirm the Prophet Muhammad and acknowledge his prophethood, acknowledge the Book he brought (Al-Qur'an), practice all of Allah's commands, and abandon all of His prohibitions. Allah will perfect their reward, without any deficiency whatsoever.

Furthermore, it is explained that those who possess the opposite characteristics have wronged themselves; they are not loved by Allah and will receive a very painful punishment.
text.58:
Allah clarifies that the news conveyed to the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, concerning Prophet Isa (Jesus), Maryam (Mary), Zakaria (Zechariah) and his son Yahya (John), and the stories of the Hawariyun (disciples) and the Jews from the descendants of Israel, are the true stories and a correction to the various beliefs circulating among the People of the Book at that time.

In this story, there are various examples and valuable points of wisdom, so that believers can take guidance from it and understand Allah's Sharia (Islamic law) and the principles of communal life.

In the story, there is clear evidence that refutes the opinions of the Christian messengers from the people of Najran and the opinions of the Jews who deny the message of Muhammad, and the truth of the religion he brought.
text.59:
This verse was revealed in connection with the arrival of the Christian delegation from Najran who said to the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), "Why do you criticize our Prophet?" The Prophet (peace be upon him) said, "What have I said?" They replied, "You said that Isa (Jesus) is a servant of Allah." Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) said, "Yes, that is true, he is a servant of Allah, a messenger, and His word which He bestowed on Maryam (Mary), a pure virgin."

Then they became angry and said, "Have you ever seen a human being born without a father? So if you are truthful, then show us an example." Then Allah revealed this verse.

This verse explains that the amazing event of Isa's (Jesus') birth is actually like the creation of Adam, who was created from dust. Both were created by Allah in a way different from the creation of ordinary humans. The similarity is that Isa (Jesus) was created without a father, and Adam was created without a father and without a mother.

The denial of people regarding the birth of Isa (Jesus) without a father, while they acknowledge the creation of Adam without a mother and father, is something that contradicts logic.

Allah created Adam as a human being by giving a soul into his body, solely because of His will, and when Allah says: "Be, and it is." (Ali Imran/3: 59). In another verse, Allah says:

¦ Then We developed it into another creation. ¦ (al-Mu'minun/23: 14).

The verse above (59) is part of a series with the following two verses, revealed in the year of delegations, the 10th year of Hijri.
text.60:
The meaning of "That is the truth from your Lord" is that what Allah has informed Muhammad, peace be upon him, about Prophet Isa (Jesus) and Maryam (Mary) is the truth, not what the Christians have said, that Al-Masih (the Messiah) is the son of God; nor is it like the assumption of the Jews that Prophet Isa was the result of adultery between Maryam and Yusuf an-Najjar (Yusuf the carpenter or Yusuf the brother of Eli). Thus, the Muslims have obtained convincing knowledge regarding Isa and Maryam.

This prohibition is directed to Prophet Muhammad so that he does not doubt, even though it is impossible for Prophet Muhammad to doubt the verses of Allah. This has two meanings:

1. That when Prophet Muhammad heard this verse, his conviction increased, and he felt satisfied with his conviction.

2. If Prophet Muhammad, who has a high position, is forbidden to doubt the truth of the story, then his ummah (community) is even more subject to this prohibition.
text.61:
In this verse, Allah commands the Prophet Muhammad, if there are still people who dispute the truth of the news about the event of Jesus (peace be upon him), after receiving an explanation, they should be invited to *mubahalah* (mutual imprecation) to prove who is right and pray that Allah SWT inflict His curse upon those who lie. This *mubahalah* serves as a reflection of the truth of the belief.

Allah commands the Prophet Muhammad to invite their respective families, both from his side and from their side, consisting of children and wives, to hold this *mubahalah*.

The verse mentions the Prophet's wives and children first in the *mubahalah*, because a person is more concerned about their family than themselves. This implies that the Prophet Muhammad, believed with full conviction that the unwanted disaster, as a result of the *mubahalah*, would not befall his family and himself. This verse is then known as the *ayat mubahalah* (verse of imprecation).

Regarding the occurrence of the invitation to *mubahalah*, it has been narrated through various sources that the Prophet Muhammad invited the Christians from the city of Najran in Yemen to hold a *mubahalah*, but they refused.

Imam al-Bukhari and Imam Muslim also narrated a hadith that the Najran delegation, led by al-'Aqib and as-Sayid, visited Rasulullah. Then he desired to hold a *mubahalah* (oath) with them. Then one of them said to his people, "Do not engage in *muhabalah* with him. By Allah, if he is truly a Prophet and he engages in *mubahalah* with us, we will never be happy forever, and there will be no generation to continue our lineage." Then they said to the Prophet, "We will give you what you ask for, so send us a trustworthy man." Then the Prophet SAW said, "Stand up, O Abu 'Ubaidah," so after he stood up, the Prophet said, "This is the trustworthy one among this ummah." (Narrated by al-Bukhari from Huzaifah).

Abu Nu'aim also narrated a hadith from Ibn 'Abbas in the book *ad-Dala'il* through a chain of narrators from 'Atha' from Adh-ahak from Ibn 'Abbas that eight Christians from the people of Najran came to Rasulullah. Among them were 'Aqib and as-Sayid. Then Allah revealed this verse. Then they said, "Give us a respite of three days." Then they went to Bani Quraizah, Bani Nadir, and Bani Qainuqa from among the Jews. Then they signaled to make peace and not hold a *mubahalah* with the Prophet. Then they said, "He is the prophet whose coming has been foretold in the Torah." Then they made peace with the Prophet SAW with an agreement to pay 1,000 pieces of clothing in the month of Safar and another 1,000 pieces along with a sum of money in the month of Rajab.

It is narrated that the Prophet Muhammad SAW, had proposed Ali, Fatimah, and their two sons (Hasan and Husain) besides himself, for *muhabalah*, and the Prophet went out with them, saying, "When I pray, let you say, 'Amin'."

Ibn 'Asakir narrated a hadith from Ja'far from his father, that after this verse was revealed, the Prophet brought Abu Bakar together with his children, Umar and his children, and Usman with his children. It can be understood from these verses that the Prophet Muhammad, had commanded to invite those who oppose the reality of the event of Jesus (peace be upon him) from among the People of the Book to gather, whether men, women, or children, and also the Prophet gathered the believers, whether men, women, or children. They then invited each other to *mubahalah* to Allah SWT so that He would curse those who deliberately lie.

The Prophet's invitation to *mubahalah* shows his full conviction in the truth of what he said, while the reluctance of the Christians and Jews who were invited to *mubahalah* shows the falsehood and falsity of their beliefs.
text.62:
The story revealed to Prophet Muhammad, concerning Prophet Isa (Jesus), is the truth, not the opinion of the Christians nor the opinion of the Jews.

There is no God worthy of worship except Allah, because Allah created everything and nothing can be compared to Him. In this verse, there is a clear refutation of the Christians who say that Allah is one of three persons.

In another verse, Allah says:

"Surely they have disbelieved who say: Allah is the third of the three." (al-Ma'idah/5: 73).

Then Allah affirms again that Allah is the All-Mighty, the All-Wise, and nothing can rival Him.
text.63:
If they reject the religion of monotheism, it means they are among those who commit corruption. They are considered to have turned away because they refuse to follow and affirm the prophethood of Muhammad, and are unwilling to accept the belief in the oneness of God brought by him, and do not dare to accept the invitation to *mubahalah* (mutual imprecation).

Allah is All-Knowing of the mentality of those who commit corruption and possess evil intentions that they conceal in their hearts.
text.64:
Allah commanded Prophet Muhammad to invite the People of the Book, namely the Jews and Christians, to engage in fair dialogue in seeking common ground from the teachings brought by the messengers and the books revealed to them, namely the Torah, the Gospel, and the Al-Qur'an. Then Allah explained the purpose of this invitation, which was so that they would not worship other than Allah, who possesses absolute power, who has the right to create sharia and has the right to permit and prohibit, and not associate partners with Him.

This verse contains: *Tauhid Uluhiyah* for Allah, which is the oneness of Allah as mentioned in His word:

¦ that we do not worship except Allah ¦ (Ali 'Imran/3: 64).

The attribute of *Tauhid Rububiyah* in His word, which is oneness in managing His creation:

¦and that we do not take one another as lords besides Allah. ¦. (Ali 'Imran/3: 64)

This provision is agreed upon by everyone and can be proven. Ibrahim a.s. (Abraham, peace be upon him) was sent by Allah to bring the religion of *tauhid*, as was Prophet Musa (Moses, peace be upon him) as found in the Torah; Allah said to Prophet Musa, "Indeed, the Lord is your deity, you have no other deity besides Me, do not make carved idols, and do not make any image of anything that is in the heavens and on earth, or that is in the water. Do not prostrate to idols and images and do not enslave yourselves to them." Likewise, Prophet Isa (Jesus, peace be upon him) was sent by Allah with the same teachings.

Then Prophet Muhammad saw (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) as the final Prophet, he was sent with the same teachings. In the Al-Qur'an, there is the word of Allah:

Allah - there is no deity except Him, the Ever-Living, the Sustainer of [all] existence. Neither drowsiness overtakes Him nor sleep. ¦(al-Baqarah/2: 255).

The conclusion of this invitation is: Muslims and the People of the Book both believe that the universe is a creation of Allah the One and Only. He is the One who created and manages it, and He is the One who sent the prophets to them to convey explanations about deeds that are pleasing and displeasing to Him.

Then Prophet Muhammad invited the People of the Book to agree to uphold the principles of religion, reject doubtful matters that contradict the principles of religion. So, if Christians find explanations from the teachings brought by Prophet Isa, such as the words "Son of God," they should interpret them with interpretations that do not contradict the principles agreed upon by the prophets, because we will not find among the words of the prophets anything that can be interpreted as meaning that Prophet Isa is indeed a god to be worshipped. We will also not find any explanation stating that Isa a.s. invited people to worship him and his mother, but rather Prophet Isa invited people to worship Allah the One and Only and to sincerely worship Him.

Initially, the Jews adhered to the religion of *tauhid*, then a disaster befell them, namely when they acknowledged that any law established by religious leaders was equal in status to the law that came from Allah. Likewise, the Christians followed a path like the Jews. They added the absolution of sins to their religion. This became a very dangerous problem in Christian society, leading to the sale of indulgences (letters of remission of sins) from the church. In this way, they were able to collect a lot of money. Therefore, a movement arose demanding reform. This group is known as Protestants.

It is narrated from 'Adi bin Hatim that he said, "I came to the Messenger of Allah saw, while around my neck was a cross made of gold. Then the Messenger of Allah said, "O 'Adi, throw that idol from your neck." I also heard Prophet Muhammad reciting Surah at-Taubah:

They have taken their scholars and monks as lords besides Allah, ¦. (at-Taubah/9: 31).

Then 'Adi said to him, "O Messenger of Allah, they do not worship the priests." Then the Messenger of Allah said, "Did they not make lawful and unlawful for you, and you adhered to their words?" Then 'Adi replied, "That is true." Then Prophet Muhammad said, "That is the worship of those priests."

The Jews and Christians rejected and disobeyed; and they remained steadfast in their stance, which is to worship other than Allah and believe in the existence of gods besides Allah, who are made intermediaries to Allah. They obey their provisions, both regarding what is made lawful and what is made unlawful by those priests. Allah swt (may He be glorified and exalted) commanded that Muslims say to them that Muslims only worship Allah and only obey Him alone.

In this verse, there is a provision that all matters related to worship or to halal and haram are only found in the Al-Qur'an and Hadith, which are used as the basis for determining them, not priests, leaders, or even the opinions of renowned legal experts. Because if that were the case, it would certainly lead to partnership in the oneness of *rububiyah* and deviation from the guidance of the Al-Qur'an as mentioned in the word of Allah:

Or have they other deities who have ordained for them a religion for which Allah has not given permission? And if not for the decisive word, judgment would have been rendered between them. And indeed, the wrongdoers will have a painful punishment. (asy-Syura/42: 21)

It is also mentioned in the word of Allah:

And do not say about what your tongues assert of untruth, "This is lawful and this is unlawful," ¦ (an-Nahl/16: 116).

As for matters that are not directly related to the afterlife and worship, such as matters of justice and political affairs, Allah has delegated His authority to knowledgeable people, such as *Ahlul Halli wal 'Aqdi*, who are experts in various fields in society. So, what they determine must be obeyed as long as it does not contradict the principles of religion. This verse is the basis and foundation for the *dakwah* of the Prophet saw to invite the People of the Book to practice it. At the time the Prophet invited them to enter Islam, as found in his letters addressed to Heraclius, Muqauqis, and Kisra of Persia.
text.65:
Allah censures the actions of the Jews and Christians who are always in disagreement regarding the purity of their respective religions, because they consider their religion to be the most correct.

The People of the Book, the Jews and Christians, are rebuked for why they disagree and argue in matters of the religion of their ancestor, Prophet Ibrahim. The Jews say that Prophet Ibrahim was a Jew, and the Christians say that Prophet Ibrahim embraced Christianity. They hold this opinion because Prophet Ibrahim is considered a symbol of high status for each group. In their books, there is praise for Ibrahim a.s., both in the Old Testament and the New Testament, just as the Quraysh also glorified his name, and they also acknowledged that their religion was in accordance with the religion of Ibrahim.

According to the statement of the Qur'an, their claim is completely unfounded, because Ibrahim's teachings leave no trace in their religious ceremonies. The truth is that Prophet Ibrahim embraced a religion that was in accordance with the religion revealed to Prophet Muhammad.

A similar provision has been indicated by Allah's word, that the Torah and the Gospel were revealed by Allah after the coming of Ibrahim. Logically, because the two Books were revealed after Ibrahim, there should not have been such disagreements and arguments. The great disagreement shows the untruth of the reasons they put forward, because it is impossible for what comes first to follow what comes after.

That is why Allah rebukes them, "Do they not think?" This shows that if they were willing to think, such arguments would not have occurred. In this case, there is a strong indication that shows the weakness of their minds and their *hujjah* (argumentation).

Regarding the *sabab nuzul* (reason for revelation) of this verse, Ibn Ishaq and Ibn Jarir have presented a narration from Ibn 'Abbas, he said, "Christians from Najran and several Jewish priests gathered before Prophet Muhammad saw, then they disagreed. The priests said: Prophet Ibrahim did not embrace any religion except Judaism. While the Christians said: Prophet Ibrahim did not embrace any religion except Christianity."
text.66:
It is indeed natural for people to argue about the matter of Prophet Isa (Jesus), and it is also natural that their arguments are based on things they know.

However, it turns out that among those who argue, some are involved in excessive issues, to the point of acknowledging that Prophet Isa is God. Conversely, some accuse him of being a boaster and a liar. This happens because each party does not know the truth, so each party cannot avoid mistakes.

Furthermore, Allah rebukes the Jews and Christians who argue about the religion of Prophet Ibrahim, because this action is not based on correct reasoning and knowledge. Wouldn't it be better and more reasonable if they simply followed the revelation that was revealed to Prophet Muhammad, which truly comes from Allah, who has vast and unlimited knowledge? Therefore, Allah affirms to them that Allah knows everything, both the manifest and the unmanifest, the visible and the invisible.

This shows that regarding matters that are unseen (ghaib), people should not debate them and should not affirm them except for what has been explained by revelation (wahyu). In other words, human knowledge is limited by scope, time, and place, while the knowledge of Allah SWT is not bound by these provisions.
text.67:
Allah provides clarity to those who debate the true identity of Prophet Ibrahim (an-Nisa'/4:125). This verse is a response to the debate between Jews and Christians regarding the religion of Prophet Ibrahim. Each of them claimed that Ibrahim adhered to the religion they practiced. Their opinions were actually false because they were not based on concrete evidence. The truth is the explanation based on revelation that Muslims believe, because Muslims embrace a religion like the religion embraced by Prophet Ibrahim, and Islam has the principles brought by Prophet Ibrahim. It is clear that Prophet Ibrahim did not embrace Christianity, nor was he a follower of Judaism, but Prophet Ibrahim was one who was obedient to Allah, steadfast in adhering to Allah's guidance, and submissive and obedient to all that He commanded.

Prophet Ibrahim did not adhere to the beliefs of the polytheists, namely the Quraysh infidels and other Arab tribes, who considered themselves followers of the religion of Prophet Ibrahim. From this verse, it can be understood that Prophet Ibrahim was a person honored by all parties, whether Jews, Christians, or polytheists. But unfortunately, their opinions are not correct, because Prophet Ibrahim did not practice a religion like their religions. He was a Muslim who was sincere to Allah, never associating partners with Him in the slightest.
text.68:
The people most entitled to be supporters of Prophet Ibrahim and the most faithful to his religion are not those who merely claim that Prophet Ibrahim embraced their religion, but those who follow in Prophet Ibrahim's footsteps and continue his da'wah (propagation of the faith). Of course, these are the people who adhere to the religion of Tawhid (Oneness of God) and sincerely practice their religion. They must be people who submit themselves to Allah alone, far from the characteristics of shirk (polytheism). These similar characteristics are found in Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, and his followers. They embrace the religion of Tawhid, and there is not even a trace in their religion of teachings that worship leaders or justify intermediaries in the relationship between humans and God. They are sincere and perform deeds solely for Allah, not because of shirk or riya (showing off).

All of this is the core of Islamic teachings. Therefore, if there is a religion that does not have these principles, then that religion is far astray and only remnants remain.

Then Allah promises that He will give help, strength, and taufik (divine guidance) to the believers because Allah controls and manages their affairs, improves their condition, and gives rewards according to how much or how little they practice Islamic teachings.
text.69:
The efforts of a group of the People of the Book will be in vain, and their deceit will befall themselves, because their actions are always directed towards the goal of misleading the believers. They have no opportunity to pay attention to how to obtain guidance. Their vision will be closed so that they cannot see the truth of the verses revealed to the Prophet Muhammad, which provide an explanation of the truth of his prophethood. It can be said that they do not think properly; they even waste their intellect, and they have also corrupted their own *fitrah* (natural disposition) so that they cannot reach the truth.

The attitude and actions of a group of the People of the Book are condemned because they do not realize their bad situation. They eventually fall into the valley of error and can no longer see the truth that leads to the straight path.

"Many of the People of the Book wish they could turn you back to disbelief after you have believed, out of envy from themselves..." (al-Baqarah/2: 109)

"They wish you would disbelieve as they disbelieved so you would be alike [with them]..." (an-Nisa'/4: 89)

Thus, it can be known that the aim of the People of the Book in raising doubtful issues among the Muslims is none other than to mislead the believers from the true religion, so that they deny the teachings of the Prophet Muhammad, *peace and blessings be upon him* (saw).
text.70: Allah censures the People of the Book who deny the verses of Allah; even though they know in their own scriptures about the coming of the Prophet Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him. Then Allah SWT emphasizes that they themselves not only knew that the Prophet Muhammad would come, but also knew his characteristics. They should have acknowledged the prophethood of Muhammad, but because of the envy that gripped their souls, they fell into the valley of humiliation. They could no longer see the radiance of truth, so they were tossed about in error.
text.71:
It is narrated by Ibn Ishaq from Ibn 'Abbas that 'Abdullah bin as-shaif, 'Adi bin Zaid, and Haris bin 'Auf were conversing with each other. "Let us believe in the book revealed to the Messenger of Allah and his companions in the morning. Then let us deny it in the evening, so that we can confuse them, hoping they will do as we do, so that they return to their original religion." Then verses 71-73 were revealed.

Allah rebukes the People of the Book because they mix truth with falsehood. What is meant by truth in this verse is the truth brought by the prophets contained in their books, namely monotheism (tauhid), and the glad tidings of the coming of Prophet Muhammad, who would perform the same task as the previous prophets, teaching the Book and wisdom to all mankind.

While what is meant by falsehood is all the deception created by the priests and prominent leaders of the People of the Book by interpreting the verses of God with false interpretations that are far from the truth. Such interpretations are considered by them as a religion that must be followed. Their actions are also condemned.

¦. And they say, "This is from Allah," while it is not from Allah. And they speak untruth about Allah while they know. (Ali 'Imran/3: 78).

It is clear that what is meant by mixing truth with falsehood is: the deception of the People of the Book who interpret the verses of Allah and say that the interpretation comes from Allah. Meanwhile, the good news about the coming of Prophet Muhammad, they hide.

All of this shows that they did this not because of negligence or ignorance, but because of denial and envy that had nested in their hearts.
text.72:
There is a group from the People of the Book who encourage their companions to pretend to believe in the book revealed to Muhammad in the morning, then disbelieve in it in the evening. They act in this way to create the impression in the hearts of Muslims that if the religion of Islam were true, then those Jews who had just converted to Islam would not apostatize again. This kind of behavior is nothing but a deception on their part to influence Muslims to return to disbelief.

Ibn Jarir narrates from Imam Mujahid, who said that a group of Jews prayed the Fajr prayer with the Prophet. Then they disbelieved in the evening. When they commit such deception, it is not strange, because they know that among the signs of truth is that if someone knows something is true, they will not abandon it. This can be understood from the statement of Heraclius, the Roman Emperor, to Abu Sufyan when he asked him about the state of Muhammad, that is, when the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) called Heraclius with his letter to embrace Islam, "Is there anyone who has left his religion after embracing it?" Abu Sufyan replied, "No."

This verse warns the Prophet Muhammad about the deception of the People of the Book and informs him of their strategy, so that the deception does not affect the hearts of believers who are still weak. This warning is useful for thwarting their efforts; because if the background of their deception is known, then their efforts will certainly not succeed. This verse is a miracle for the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him), because it contains unseen news that reveals the secret of the evil intentions of the Jews.
text.73:
Allah reveals the existence of statements from Jewish leaders forbidding their people from declaring their beliefs to non-Jews, namely that prophethood could be given by Allah to others besides the Jews. For if this were said to the Muslims, they would certainly use it as a reason to strengthen the apostleship of Muhammad, who was sent by Allah from among the Arabs, not from among the Jews. This kind of attitude arose because the Jews indeed knew that Allah could send a messenger, even if not from the Jewish people, but they denied the prophethood of Muhammad because of their arrogance and envy.

Indeed, the guidance that is newly followed is the guidance of Allah. Meaning that guidance is not only for one particular nation among His servants. That guidance is conveyed through the prophets appointed by Allah according to His will. Therefore, whoever is given guidance by Allah SWT, he will not be misguided, and no one can mislead him. So, the deceit of the People of the Book will not have the slightest influence on Muslims, and nothing can hinder Allah's will towards His prophets.

Apostleship is a gift from the Lord that is absolutely within His power. Allah is the All-Giver and All-Knowing, who is entitled to receive His grace. So, Allah will give His grace to those who deserve to receive it. In this statement, there is a warning that the Jews have narrowed the understanding of the grace of the All-Encompassing Lord.

The grace of Allah is vast, and His mercy is given equally according to His will. This is a refutation of the accusation of the People of the Book who say that prophethood and apostleship are only for the Children of Israel (Bani Israil).

Thus, it can be understood that Allah has the absolute right to send prophets and messengers according to His justice and mercy.
text.74:
The mercy of Allah bestowed upon the prophets is solely a gift from Allah. Allah's bounty is vast, and His mercy is widespread to every servant. No one can influence Allah in bestowing that bounty. Therefore, Allah has the right to increase His mercy and bounty upon His servants according to His justice, unlike the opinion of the People of the Book that Allah's mercy and bounty are only for them. Thus, Allah has unlimited power to send prophets according to His will. If Allah sends a prophet from a particular nation, it is solely due to the abundance of His bounty and mercy.

From this verse, it can be understood that Allah's judgment of a person is fundamentally the same. No one is superior to another except through their taqwa (piety/God-consciousness). That virtue only comes from Allah, bestowed upon a person according to His will.
text.75:
This verse explains that among the People of the Book, there is a group of people who, when entrusted with a large or small amount of wealth, return it according to the trust given to them. However, there are also those among them who, when entrusted with even a small amount of wealth, refuse to return it unless they are demanded, and only then will they surrender it after a process of proof.

This shows that among the People of the Book, there is a group of people whose job is to make things difficult for Muslims and to create deception so that Muslims are not happy to embrace their religion and turn back to follow their religion. Among them, there is also a group of people whose job is to distort the law. They justify consuming the wealth of others by arguing that: "The Torah forbids betraying trusts against their co-religionists. If the betrayal is committed against other nations, they allow it." In short, the People of the Book can be divided into two groups:

1.  People of the Book who truly adhere to the Torah and are truly trustworthy. For example, Abdullah bin Salam, who was entrusted with a large amount of wealth by the Quraysh and then returned it.

2.  People of the Book who cannot be trusted because if they are entrusted with wealth, even a small amount, they deny it and refuse to return it unless it is proven with reasonable evidence or through a process of proof in court.

An example is Ka'ab bin al-Ashraf, who was entrusted with one dinar by the Quraysh and then denied the trust.

The reasons they do this are because they believe that they are not sinful if they do not fulfill a trust to a Muslim, because they believe that there is no threat and no sin if they consume the wealth of a Muslim in a wrongful manner.

In short, it can be said that, according to their opinion, everyone other than the Jewish people will not be noticed by Allah, and they even receive wrath from Allah. Therefore, their wealth will not be protected, and taking their wealth is not considered a sin. There is no doubt that such an assumption is a denial, deception, and insult to religion.

The meaning is that they know and realize that they are deliberately lying in this matter, even though they know that there is not even a single provision in the Torah that allows betraying the Arabs and consuming the wealth of Muslims unlawfully.

In reality, they already know this, but they do not adhere to the Torah. They are more inclined to blindly follow the words of their religious leaders and consider it a provision that they must follow. In fact, their leaders put forward their opinions regarding matters related to religion by using interpretation with reason and taste. They do not hesitate to change the original structure of the Torah to strengthen their opinions. They defend that opinion by looking for reasons that can strengthen it.

It is also narrated by Ibn Munzir from Sa'id bin Jubair, who said: After verse 75 was revealed, the Messenger of Allah said:

"The enemies of Allah (the Jews) have lied. There is no provision in the time of ignorance (jahiliyyah) except that it is under these two feet of mine (has been canceled) except for trust (amanat). This trust is obligatory upon the good and the evil." (Narrated by Ibn Mundhir from Sa'id bin Jubair)
text.76:
The opinion of the Children of Israel who said that there was no sin for them if they committed evil against Muslims is refuted. Then Allah affirms that everyone should always fulfill all kinds of promises and carry out the trusts entrusted to them.

If someone lends you property for a fixed period, or someone sells goods that have been determined, or someone entrusts goods, then the provisions that have been agreed upon together must be fulfilled. A person's property should be given precisely on time without waiting for a bill or waiting until the matter is brought to court. This is what is desired by the provisions of the Sharia.

In this verse, there is a warning that the Jews do not want to keep their promises simply because of the promise itself, but they see with whom they are making the promise. If they make an agreement with the Children of Israel, they consider it obligatory to fulfill it, but if they make an agreement with those other than the Children of Israel, they do not consider it obligatory to fulfill it.

Allah mentions the reward for those who keep their promises to give the understanding that keeping promises is an act that is pleasing to Allah and that those who keep their promises will receive His mercy in this world and in the hereafter.

In this verse, it is explained that the principle of religion, namely keeping promises and not breaking them, as well as protecting oneself from committing sins, is an act that draws one closer to Allah, and deserves to receive an abundance of His love and affection.
text.77:
Regarding the *sabab nuzul* (reason for revelation) of this verse, it is explained in a hadith narrated by al-Bukhari and other hadith scholars that al-Asy'ats bin Qais said, "I had a land lease agreement with a Jew, and he denied it. Therefore, I brought it to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him)." Then the Messenger of Allah said, "Do you have proof?" I said, "No." After that, the Messenger of Allah said to the Jew, "Take an oath." Then I said, "O Messenger of Allah! If that's the case, he will swear. (And if he swears) then my wealth will be lost." Then Allah revealed this verse.

In this verse, various consequences are explained that will be suffered by those who break Allah's covenant and violate their oaths for a cheap price or reward.

What is meant by "Allah's covenant" in this verse is Allah's commands and prohibitions that are conveyed through the messengers mentioned in His books. Such as being truthful, fulfilling promises that have been made, conveying trusts to those who have the right to receive them, worshipping Allah without associating partners with Him, and being mindful of Him in all matters. What is meant by their oaths is the declaration they have made that they will always follow the truth.

What is meant by "exchanging Allah's covenant for a small price" (cheap) is denying Allah's covenant for worldly deeds that are considered better. All kinds of denial are considered low or worthless compared to the blessings that will be obtained if Allah's covenant is fulfilled.

As for the consequences that will be suffered by those who dare to exchange Allah's covenant for worldly pleasures, they will not receive any reward in the Hereafter in the form of abundant blessings. They will not receive attention from Allah on the Day of Judgment, nor will they receive any forgiveness of sins.

According to al-Qaffal's explanation, what is meant by Allah's statement, "And Allah will not speak to them," is a depiction of Allah's intense anger towards them. In short, it can be said that Allah strongly threatens those who break agreements and deny promises. They will not obtain rewards in the Hereafter, they will suffer painful torment, they are hated by Allah and will no longer receive His mercy.
text.78:
This verse explains the situation of another group of the People of the Book, namely a group of their priests who altered the verses of the Book (Torah) by adding words, changing their order, or deleting parts of the words, thus changing their original meaning. They recited these altered verses as if they were reciting the verses of al-Kitab, so that the listeners would think that what was being read was truly a verse of al-Kitab, when in fact what was being read did not come from Allah, but was their own creation.

They knew that what they were doing was wrong, but they still did it. This was because their piety towards Allah had disappeared, and they believed that Allah would forgive any sins they committed because they were religious people.

The heinous actions of the Jews serve as a lesson for Muslims so that no one among the Muslims behaves in such a way, and no one believes that Muslims are guaranteed forgiveness from Allah no matter how great their sins. Nor should there be anyone who claims to be Muslim but whose actions are those of disbelievers and hypocrites, unwilling to practice the teachings of the Al-Qur'an and the Sunnah of the Prophet, and whose beliefs are not in accordance with the beliefs of Muslims.
text.79:
It is impossible and inappropriate for a human being to whom Allah has given the Book, knowledge of religious matters, and elevated to prophethood, to then invite people to worship himself instead of worshipping Allah. One who has been given such virtues would certainly invite people to learn about the attributes of Allah, study religious laws, and set a good example in obeying Allah and worshipping Him, as well as teaching the Book to all people.

A Prophet, as a human being who has been given the aforementioned virtues, would certainly not and should not command others to worship him, because he is a creation of Allah. Therefore, his Creator, Allah, is the One who must be worshipped. He is affirmed to command people to be mindful of Allah, to teach the Al-Kitab and implement it, as affirmed by the word of Allah:

Say, "Only Allah do I worship, sincere to Him in my religion." (az-Zumar/39: 14)

Whoever commands people to worship him, it means he acknowledges that Allah has a partner, namely himself. Whoever associates partners with Allah, it means he has eliminated the purity of worship to Allah alone. With the loss of the purity of worship, the meaning of worship is also lost.

Unquestionably, for Allah is the pure religion. And those who take protectors besides Him [say], "We only worship them that they may bring us nearer to Allah." Indeed, Allah will judge between them concerning that over which they differ. (az-Zumar/39: 3)

Similarly, the word of Allah recounting the call of Prophet Hud to his people:

That you not worship except Allah. Indeed, I fear for you the punishment of a painful day." (Hud/11: 26)

All prophets commanded people to worship Allah:

And to the Thamud [We sent] their brother Salih. He said, "O my people, worship Allah; you have no deity other than Him. (Hud/11: 61)
text.80: It is not fitting for a human being to whom Allah has given the Scripture, wisdom, and prophethood to then say to the people, "Be worshippers of me rather than of Allah." This was never done by any of the Prophets, including the Prophet Muhammad (saw). What did happen was that the Arabs worshipped angels. The Jews worshipped Uzair, and the Christians worshipped Al-Masih (the Messiah), who they considered the son of God. All these actions are contrary to the teachings brought by the prophets because all the prophets commanded people to worship Allah, the One and Only.
text.81:
Allah has taken a covenant from the prophets that whenever a messenger comes to them confirming the scripture they possess, they will believe in him and help him, they will trust him, even though they themselves have been given the Book and wisdom. This is because the purpose of sending the prophets and messengers is one, namely to convey the teachings of Allah. Therefore, the messengers must help one another.

In addition, if a later sharia brings provisions that change or abolish provisions from the previous sharia, it must be accepted, because the teachings related to the fundamental principles of religion related to faith and divinity brought by the prophets are the same. However, matters related to sharia (law) such as criminal law and civil law in each religion may differ, adjusted to the circumstances of time and place.

What is meant by "Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) confirming the previous messengers and the books they brought" is confirming that Allah has sent those messengers and revealed books to them, and it does not mean that Muhammad (peace be upon him) confirms the entire contents of those books as they exist now.

In this verse, there is a strong indication that religion should not be a source of hostility and hatred, as has been done by the People of the Book who are hostile to Muhammad, making it difficult for them to return to the same principles, even hindering, opposing, and denying his call.

In short, it can be said that if the People of the Book were willing to understand and think about the common principles brought by the prophets, they would surely be able to accept and follow the teachings brought by Prophet Muhammad and confirm His sharia, in accordance with the promise that had been declared by Prophet Musa and Prophet Isa, namely that whenever a prophet comes after them, confirming the scripture they possess, they will believe in him.
