If the Jews and Christians believe in Prophet Musa and Prophet Isa, then they must also believe in what those two prophets believed in. Furthermore, it is explained that the prophets' covenant that had been agreed upon together was witnessed by each party, and Allah is also a witness to their pledge.
text.82: Whoever turns away from the covenant that has been pledged, they are the transgressors (fasik). Those meant by "those who turn away" are the Jews who lived during the time of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him). They did not believe in the prophethood of Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him), which means they did not believe in the covenant that had been pledged by Prophet Musa (Moses) and Prophet Isa (Jesus). They knew the covenant that had been pledged by Prophet Musa and Prophet Isa, and knew its contents, but they did not fulfill it. That is why they are called the transgressors (fasik).
text.83:
Allah does not justify the attitude of the People of the Book, but rather condemns them because they deviated from the truth, after the truth became clear to them, and they refused to embrace the religion of Islam that came from Allah. Allah SWT rebukes them for why they act in such a way, even though all the heavens and the earth submit to Allah voluntarily and are subject to His decrees.

In short, it can be explained that the Jews do not believe in the religion brought by the Prophet Muhammad SAW, even though their prophets believed in the Prophet Muhammad SAW, who would come later. By not believing in the Prophet Muhammad, it means they do not believe in their own prophets; and it means they are seeking a religion other than Islam. Their attitude is condemned by Allah because everything in the heavens and on earth submits and obeys Allah, so why do they not do the same?

Then Allah explains that to Allah is the return of all creatures, whether Jews, Christians, or other nations besides them. At that time, they will be rewarded according to their deeds in the world.

In this verse, there is a severe threat to the People of the Book, both Jews and Christians, because they have deviated from the truth and refuse to acknowledge the prophethood of Muhammad SAW.
text.84:
In this verse, Allah swt commands Muhammad, including those who follow him, to believe that Allah certainly exists. He is One and has unlimited power over the entire contents of the universe, and also commands him to believe in the Book of Al-Qur'an which was revealed to him. In addition to believing that Allah swt revealed revelations to the previous Prophets, namely Prophet Ibrahim, Ismail, Ishaq, Yaqub, the prophets of Yaqub's descendants, and the revelations conveyed to Musa, Isa and other prophets sent by Allah, which function as guidance for their people. The revelations conveyed to the prophets have the same principles and levels.

"Indeed, We have revealed to you (Muhammad) as We revealed to Noah and the prophets after him..." (an-Nisa'/4: 163)

Prophet Musa and Prophet Isa are mentioned specifically in this verse, because the discussion in this verse and the verses before and after it are related to Christians and Jews.

After that, other prophets are mentioned to give believers an idea so that they also believe in other prophets and the revelations revealed to them, such as Prophet Dawud, Prophet Ayyub and others. This also includes prophets who received revelations, but Allah did not narrate them to us in the Al-Qur'an.

The command to believe in the book revealed to Prophet Muhammad is mentioned before the command to believe in the books revealed to the prophets who were sent before. Even though in reality, these books were revealed before the Al-Qur'an, this is to emphasize that the Al-Qur'an is a true source for knowing the books revealed to the previous prophets, and because the Al-Qur'an acknowledges the truth of the books revealed previously. Therefore, the prophethood of the prophets mentioned in the Al-Qur'an must be believed in principle, in accordance with the information provided by the Al-Qur'an.

Furthermore, Allah commands Prophet Muhammad saw and his ummah to say that he and his ummah do not differentiate the degrees of the messengers, therefore believers should not believe in some of the contents of the Al-Qur'an but deny others, as the Jews and Christians did to their books.

A believer should purify himself from sinful deeds. This verse begins with a command to believe in Allah and ends with a command to "surrender, obey and submit" before providing an explanation of the purpose of every religion brought by the prophets.
text.85:
Allah has decreed that whoever seeks a religion other than Islam, or refuses to submit to the ordinances of Allah, their faith will not be accepted by Allah. An example is given: the polytheists and those who claim to adhere to monotheism but associate partners with Allah. Like the People of the Book, followers of Christianity, who fail to bring their adherents to submit under the authority of Allah. Such a religion is merely a tradition, which cannot bring benefit to its adherents, but instead drags them into the valley of destruction, becomes a source of enmity among people in the world, and becomes the cause of their regret in the Hereafter.

Whoever seeks a religion other than Islam to be their religion, in the Hereafter will be among those who are lost, because they have wasted the *akidah tauhid* (the creed of monotheism) which is in accordance with human nature (*fitrah*).
text.86:
Regarding the reason for the revelation of verses 86 to 89, a hadith narrated by Ibn Jarir, An-Nasa'i, al-Hakim, and Ibn Hibban can be presented:

That Ibn 'Abbas said, "There was a man from the Ansar who had embraced Islam, then he apostatized and joined the ranks of the polytheists, but he regretted it. Then he asked his people to ask the Messenger of Allah (saw), "Can my repentance be accepted?" Then (verse 86) to (verse 89) were revealed. Then this was conveyed to him, and he returned to Islam."

Those who revert to disbelief after having believed, Allah will not grant them a way to obtain guidance. Because they do not acknowledge the good news about the coming of the Prophet Muhammad, which is contained in their books. Initially, they desired to follow the Prophet Muhammad if they were given a long life, and if the new prophet was sent from among them. But after it became clear that the Prophet Muhammad (saw) had come, and he was not from among them, they denied him, even though the coming of the Prophet Muhammad was accompanied by clear evidence of his prophethood. Those who initially believed and then disbelieved again, they wrong themselves, and Allah will not guide those who wrong themselves, because Allah has explained that guidance to the right path can only be effective if a person's soul is pure, so that he can receive evidence of the truth from that guidance. But if a person's heart has been tainted by injustice, then he will deviate from the right path. Therefore, it is no longer possible for them to receive Allah's guidance.
text.87:
They deserve the wrath of Allah, the angels, and all of mankind, and people in general will curse those who apostatize from their faith, in accordance with Allah's saying:

And he (Abraham) said, "You have only taken, besides Allah, idols as a bond of affection among you in worldly life. Then on the Day of Resurrection you will deny one another and curse one another, and your refuge will be the Fire, and you will have no helpers." (al-'Ankabut/29: 25)
text.88: Those who disbelieve after having believed will receive wrath and punishment from Allah forever. They will abide eternally in Hell, without any relief whatsoever. They will not receive forgiveness for any reason, because what causes them to experience this punishment is the denial and disbelief that has permeated their hearts. Therefore, the wrath of Allah cannot be avoided for any reason, and the punishment of Allah against them cannot be postponed.
text.89:
For those who truly repent from their deeds and return to the right path, abandoning their disbelief, then genuinely regretting their wrongdoings and improving their future by filling it with righteous deeds, willing to cultivate their faith with correct teachings, and wanting to change their evil behavior that pollutes their souls, the door of repentance is still opened as wide as possible for them.

In this verse, there is an indication that the repentance of a person who repents but does not prove it with good deeds is meaningless in the eyes of religion. Many people declare that they have repented, accompanied by regret and istighfar, but then they repeat their evil deeds. The repentance of such people has no effect whatsoever on their souls and is unable to cure their disease. If they could prove their repentance in the form of real actions, they would surely receive forgiveness from Allah and receive His mercy.
text.90:
The disbelievers referred to in this verse are the People of the Book who believed in the coming of Prophet Muhammad, as mentioned in their scriptures. However, after Prophet Muhammad came and was appointed as a messenger, they disbelieved by denying, opposing, and antagonizing him. For such people, their repentance will never be accepted by Allah.

Allah's affirmation that their repentance will not be accepted in this verse differs from the affirmation in previous verses where Allah says:

"And He is the One who accepts repentance from His servants..." (ash-Shura/42: 25)

In this verse, the disbelievers referred to are the People of the Book who previously knew about the coming of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). Then, after Prophet Muhammad was sent, they denied him. Their disbelief increased and intensified, making it impossible for their repentance to be accepted, as explained by Allah's statement:

"...Then they increase in disbelief..." (Ali 'Imran/3: 90)

Indeed, a good soul is one that regrets its sinful deeds and then distances itself from sin. Such a soul can still be expected to receive forgiveness. However, a dirty soul, which has become a nest of polytheism and disbelief and is gripped by impulses to commit sin, causing its heart to be shackled from seeing the light of truth, so that whenever it wants to repent, there is always something preventing it from accepting the truth. Such a soul is very difficult to cleanse back to its original state.

Then it is affirmed that they are truly misguided people because they have denied the truth. They have taken the wrong path, therefore they will not be happy. They have no hope of receiving guidance and will never receive forgiveness.
text.91:
Those who are steeped in disbelief and swayed by evil deeds, until death snatches them away while they remain in their disbelief, not even the slightest ransom will be accepted from them, even if the amount of the ransom is equivalent to the wealth of gold filling the entire earth. The meaning is, if they were to give charity with gold weighing as much as the earth's contents to be used as ransom for the sins they have committed, its reward would not be able to save them from the torment of hell because disbelief obliterates their good deeds.

What Allah values on the Day of Judgment is only faith in Allah, and the Last Day, as well as righteous deeds that draw one closer to Allah.

"So today no ransom will be taken from you or from those who disbelieved. Your refuge is the Fire. It is most worthy of you, and how evil a destination!" (al-Hadid/57: 15)

Thus, it can be said that on that day there is no way for them to save themselves, neither with their wealth nor with their position. All matters on that day are based solely on the purity of the soul, so whoever preserves the purity of their soul with faith and righteous deeds will be happy. Conversely, whoever defiles it with disbelief and evil deeds will truly lose.
text.92:
One will not attain the level of virtue in the sight of Allah until he sincerely spends of what he loves in the way of Allah. What is meant by what is loved is the wealth that we cherish. This verse is closely related to the word of Allah:

"O you who have believed, spend from the good things which you have earned..." (al-Baqarah/2:267).

After this verse was revealed, the companions of the Prophet competed in doing good deeds. Among them was Abu Talhah al-Ansari, a wealthy man among the Ansar, who came to the Prophet (saw) and gave a plot of date palm garden that he loved very much to be spent in the way of Allah.

The Prophet accepted the gift well and praised his sincerity. The Messenger of Allah advised that the wealth be spent on his close relatives, so Talhah distributed it to his close relatives. Thus, he received the reward of charity and the reward of strengthening kinship ties with his family. After that, Umar bin al-Khattab also came and handed over a plot of his garden in Khaibar. The Prophet (saw) also ordered that the garden be maintained, only the proceeds from the garden would be a waqf from Umar.
text.93:
This verse explains that all foods were permissible for the Children of Israel and also for Prophet Ibrahim, including camel meat, as mentioned in the Old Testament (Leviticus xi:4), "Nevertheless these shall ye not eat of them that chew the cud, or of them that divide the hoof: as the camel, because he cheweth the cud, but divideth not the hoof; he is unclean unto you." Only a few foods were forbidden by Prophet Yaqub himself to himself because he suffered from an illness, and all of that happened before the Torah was revealed. Then there were several kinds of food that were forbidden to the Children of Israel (see an-Nisa'/4:160, al-An'am/6:146 and their tafsir) as a punishment and lesson for their injustice, as stated in Allah's words:

And to those who are Jews, We forbade every animal with undivided hoof, and We forbade them the fat of oxen and sheep except what adheres to their backs or entrails or is mixed with bone. Thus We punished them for their wrongdoing. And indeed, We are truthful. (al-An'am/6:146).

Similarly, it is stated in the Qur'an:

For the wrongdoing of the Jews, We made unlawful for them [certain] good foods which had been lawful to them, and for their averting many from the way of Allah, and for their taking of usury while they had been forbidden from it, and for their consuming the wealth of people unjustly. And We have prepared for the disbelievers among them a painful punishment. (an-Nisa'/4:160-161).

It is clear that some types of food that were forbidden to the Children of Israel were not forbidden to the followers of the law of Prophet Ibrahim and other prophets before the Torah was revealed.

Thus, their accusation that Islamic law contradicts the law of Prophet Ibrahim because it permits eating camel meat is invalidated. Forbidding some foods for the Children of Israel was solely as a punishment because they had violated Allah's laws and had wronged themselves. This is also mentioned in the Torah, their own book.

Therefore, Prophet Muhammad was commanded by Allah to challenge them by saying, "If you say there was food forbidden by Allah before the Torah was revealed, then bring the Torah and read it, if you are truthful." Apparently, they did not dare to answer this challenge and did not want to open the Torah, because if they dared to open the Torah, their lies would be revealed and their accusations against Islam would be false and baseless. This also proves the truthfulness of the prophethood of Muhammad saw, because he was able to refute the accusations of the Children of Israel with the contents of the Torah itself, even though he had never read it and had never been given the opportunity by the Jews to know its contents.
text.94:
If the Jews still dare to fabricate lies against Allah even though their disguise has been exposed and all the reasons they put forward have been proven false, and Prophet Muhammad, with the help of revelation from his Lord, has known some of the contents of their book, then surely they are among the wrongdoers (zalim). They are not only zalim towards themselves because they will no longer be trusted and will receive Allah's punishment and torment. But they are also zalim towards others, because with that evil they mislead the people from the right path and prevent people, especially their followers, from believing in Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), the bringer of truth and as a mercy to all mankind.

Anyone who acts like that will meet with failure, will receive a bad fate, will be labeled by society as troublemakers and chaos creators, and will be angered by Allah and receive punishment in the Hereafter.
text.95:
Allah commanded Prophet Muhammad to say to the Jews that what Allah informed him through revelation, about all the foods that were originally permissible for the Children of Israel before the Torah was revealed and also permissible for the nations before Prophet Musa, was true. Indeed, some types of food were forbidden to them in the Torah as a punishment for their disobedience; all of that truly came from Allah, whose truth cannot be denied, because He is All-Knowing and All-Wise.

Therefore, the Jews should follow the teachings of Prophet Muhammad, because the religion he brought is, in principle, the same as that brought by Prophet Ibrahim. And they should not continue to prohibit camel meat and its milk, because there is no prohibition against eating its meat and drinking its milk, either in the law of Prophet Ibrahim or in the laws of other prophets, including Islamic law. Moreover, Prophet Ibrahim was not a polytheist, and the religion he brought was a pure monotheistic religion like Islam. He did not associate partners with Allah and did not worship anything other than Him, unlike their group (the Jews) who say, "Uzair is the son of Allah," and not like the Christians who say that Isa is the son of Allah.
text.96:
This verse is a response to the Jews regarding the transfer of the Qibla from Baitulmaqdis to the Kaaba. The Jews said that facing Baitulmaqdis had been justified by the prophets. Even Prophet Ibrahim himself faced it. This accusation by the Jews is refuted by verses 96 and 97.

These two verses clearly explain that the first house made as a place of worship for humans in prayer and supplication is the Kaaba in Mecca, which was built by Prophet Ibrahim a.s. and Ismail. So Mecca with its Kaaba is the first spiritual center established for mankind. After the Kaaba, Masjidilaqsa in Baitulmaqdis was built several hundred years later by Prophet Sulaiman bin Daud. Because Ibrahim built Baitullah in Mecca, it is clear that Prophet Muhammad saw. followed the religion of Prophet Ibrahim a.s. and also followed his Qibla in prayer.

After establishing the Kaaba, Prophet Ibrahim a.s. prayed that the surrounding area would be blessed by Allah:

"O our Lord! I have settled some of my offspring in a valley barren of cultivation, near Your Sacred House, our Lord, that they may establish prayer. So make hearts among the people incline toward them and provide for them from fruits that they might be grateful." (Ibrahim/14:37).

Religious historians, especially from the Abrahamic monotheistic religions, always question which house of worship is the oldest, whether it is the Haikal (Temple) of Solomon (Solomon's Temple) built by Prophet Sulaiman a.s. in Jerusalem, or Baitullah in Mecca. Which came first? The verse above states that 'the first house (of worship) appointed for men was that at Bakkah.' The ancient name of the city of Mecca is Bakkah, and this has been alluded to in the Book of Zabur (Psalm), which can be seen in the Old Testament, Psalm, 84: 5-6: "Blessed is the man whose strength is in Thee; in whose hearth are the ways of them who passing through the valley of Baca make it well." Marting Lings (1986) in his book *Muhammad, His life based on the earliest sources*-, states that Baca in the Book of Zabur above is none other than Bakkah mentioned in Surah Ä€li 'Imran/3 verse 96 above. The history of Prophet Daud a.s. is around 900 years Before Christ, or 2900 years ago. So Baka existed more than 2900 years ago, because it was mentioned in the Book of Prophet Daud a.s., the Book of Zabur above. Meanwhile, the Temple of Solomon was founded by the son of Prophet Daud a.s., namely Prophet Sulaiman a.s. It is clear that Baitullah in the city of Baka is older than the Temple of Solomon in Jerusalem.
text.97:
Another proof that Prophet Ibrahim (Abraham) re-established the Kaaba is the existence of Maqam Ibrahim next to Baitullah, which is a stone used as a standing place by Prophet Ibrahim (a.s.) when building the Kaaba together with his son, Ismail (a.s.). The imprint of his feet remains and can be witnessed until now.

Whoever enters the land of Mecca (the haram area) is guaranteed safety from the danger of enemies, and this safety is not only for humans but also for animals; they must not be disturbed, and the trees must not be cut down.

After Prophet Ibrahim re-established the Kaaba, he was commanded by Allah to call upon all of mankind to make a pilgrimage to Baitullah to perform the Hajj. This Hajj pilgrimage was initiated by Prophet Ibrahim and continues to be performed by Muslims until now as the fifth pillar of Islam. Every Muslim who is able is obligated to perform the Hajj once in their lifetime.

Whoever denies the obligation of the Hajj pilgrimage is considered among the disbelievers (kafir).
text.98: With this verse, the People of the Book who still do not affirm the prophethood of Muhammad (peace be upon him) are reproached, even though the evidence for his prophethood is abundant and clear enough. Through their denial and disbelief, they constantly strive to divide the Muslims and weaken their position.
text.99: The People of the Book wish that the religion of Allah would deviate from its true purpose by altering the characteristics of Muhammad and fabricating lies against Allah, even though they anticipate the prophethood of Muhammad, peace be upon him, in their own hearts. Allah curses the envious nature hidden in the breasts of the leaders of the People of the Book. Allah will never be heedless of their falsehood.
text.100: Believers are forbidden from following a group of the People of the Book because they are always devising schemes against the Muslims. If the Muslims were to follow the Jews, they would surely fall back into animosity and disbelief.
text.101:
Why do Muslims deny Allah and follow the People of the Book, even though they have heard the verses of Allah recited to them, and those verses are a source of guidance containing all kinds of goodness and always encourage the preservation of faith, while the Messenger of Allah himself is still in their midst as a symbol of truth, virtue, and brotherhood?

Is it then fitting for a believer who has been given such great blessings by Allah to follow a group of people who were clearly misguided before and mislead many people from the straight path? Therefore, a believer should hold fast to the teachings of Allah and His Messenger. By doing so, they will be preserved and always be within His guidance, they will never be misguided, and they will not feel fear.
text.102: It was proclaimed to the Muslims, especially the Aus and Khazraj tribes, that they should remain in Medina, believe, and fear Allah with true piety, by fulfilling all the obligations of piety. By exerting all their power and ability to carry out Allah's commands and avoid His prohibitions, in their entirety, and do not die except in a state of embracing Islam.
text.103:
They are reminded to hold fast to Allah and His teachings and to always remember the blessings He has bestowed upon them. In the days of ignorance (jahiliyah), they were enemies, leading to civil wars lasting hundreds of years, such as the war between the 'Aus and Khazraj tribes. Then Allah united their hearts with the coming of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), and they entered the religion of Islam in droves. Allah removed envy from their hearts and extinguished the fires of animosity within them, so they became brothers and sisters, loving one another and striving for shared happiness.

Also, because of polytheism (kemusyrikan), they were on the brink of the abyss of hellfire, separated only by death. But Allah saved them. Thus does Allah explain His verses, so that the Muslims may receive guidance and be grateful for the blessings, so that those blessings may be preserved.
text.104:
To achieve this goal, there needs to be a group of Muslims active in the field of da'wah (Islamic propagation) who constantly give warnings whenever signs of division and deviation appear. Therefore, this verse commands that among the Muslim community, there should be a group of people trained in the field of da'wah who firmly call to goodness, enjoin what is ma'ruf (good) and forbid what is munkar (evil/sin). In this way, the Muslim community will be protected from division and infiltration from any party.

Encouraging good deeds alone is not enough, but must be accompanied by eliminating bad qualities. Whoever wants to achieve victory must first know the requirements and tactics of the struggle to achieve it, namely that victory will not be achieved except with strength, and strength will not be realized except with unity. Strong and solid unity will not be achieved except with virtuous qualities. Virtue will not be preserved except by preserving religion, and ultimately religion cannot be preserved except with the existence of da'wah. Therefore, the first obligation of the Muslim community is to intensify da'wah so that religion can develop well and perfectly, so that it has many adherents.

With the encouragement of religion, various kinds of goodness will be achieved, so that a strong and solid unity is realized. From this strong and solid unity will arise a great ability to achieve victory in every struggle. Those who meet the conditions of the struggle are the people who are successful and fortunate.
text.105: Allah forbids Muslims from division, because division, no matter how firm and strong the position of a community, will inevitably lead to collapse and destruction. Therefore, Allah warns Muslims not to fall into the abyss of division.
text.106:
This verse describes how the two groups will appear differently on the Day of Judgment. The first group, the believers, will have faces that are bright, clean, and radiant. The second group, the disbelievers from the People of the Book and the hypocrites, will appear gloomy and their faces will be black because they see the torment that Allah has prepared for them.

In addition to receiving the torment that befalls their bodies, they will also be met with reproach from Allah with the words, "Why did you disbelieve after having believed? Therefore, taste the punishment because of your disbelief."
text.107: As for the believers, they are in the mercy of Allah, which is Paradise filled with blessings and pleasures, so that signs of happiness appear on their faces, which are white, clean, and radiant.
text.108: These are the verses of Allah that have been recited with truth, and everyone will receive recompense according to their conduct in the world. And Allah never intends to wrong His servants, for He is the Self-Sufficient and the Most Just, able to execute His perfect will, independent of anyone.
text.109: Furthermore, all things in nature, whether categorized as planets or the countless stars, belong to Allah. He has full authority to regulate all their contents with wisdom without having to answer to anyone, because He is the Creator of the universe and to Him all matters will be returned.
text.110:
This verse contains an encouragement for the believers to maintain these primary characteristics and to maintain a high spirit.

The best people in the world are those who possess two kinds of characteristics: enjoining good and forbidding evil, and always believing in Allah. All these characteristics were possessed by the Muslims during the time of the Prophet and had become ingrained in them, which is why they became strong and victorious. In a short time, they were able to bring the entire Arabian Peninsula under the submission and obedience of Islam, living safely and peacefully under the banners of justice, whereas previously they were a divided people, always in a state of chaos and fighting among themselves. This is thanks to the steadfastness of their faith and their obedience in carrying out the teachings of religion, and thanks to their perseverance and tenacity in establishing *amar makruf* (enjoining good) and preventing *munkar* (evil). The deep faith in their hearts always encourages them to strive and struggle to uphold truth and justice, as mentioned in Allah's word:

"Indeed, the true believers are those who believe in Allah and His Messenger and then doubt not, and strive with their wealth and their lives in the cause of Allah. They are the truthful." (al-hujurat/49: 15)

So there are two conditions to become the best people in the world, as explained in this verse: first, strong faith, and second, establishing *amar makruf* and preventing *munkar*. Then every people who possess these two characteristics will surely be victorious and noble, and if these two things are ignored and no longer heeded, then it cannot be regretted if that people falls into the valley of poverty.

If the People of the Book were to believe, it would certainly be better for them. But few among them believe, such as Abdullah bin Salam and his companions, and most of them are *fasik* (rebellious), unwilling to believe; they believe in some of the scriptures and disbelieve in others, or they believe in some of the messengers such as Moses and Jesus and disbelieve in the Prophet Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him.
text.111:
The People of the Book do not harm the Muslims except to hurt their feelings with vile words, or by denigrating the Prophet's character and alienating people from the religion of Islam.

All their efforts and deceptions will disappear without a trace, swallowed up by the steadfastness of faith and the perseverance in struggle possessed by the Muslims, as expressed in this verse.

(1) "They will never harm you except for [minor] annoyance." They only revile, criticize, defame Islam, try to create doubts, and slander the Prophet.

(2) "And if they fight you, they will turn their backs [in flight]." They have never succeeded in causing significant losses among the Muslims.

(3) "Then they will not be aided," to achieve victory. Indeed, they have never achieved victory in battles against Islam, even when they allied themselves with the polytheists.
text.112:
Due to the disbelief and denial of the People of the Book (Jews), as well as their excessive actions in opposing Muslims in various ways and efforts, Allah inflicted humiliation upon them wherever they were, except if they submitted and obeyed Allah's regulations and laws by paying the jizyah, which is a tax to obtain security guarantees (habl min Allah) and they obtained security from the Muslims (habl min al-nas).

But they could not carry this out in their interactions with the Prophet and his companions in Medina; instead, they always opposed and tried to weaken the position of the Muslims and continued to be hostile to Islam. Therefore, they incurred the wrath of Allah, were afflicted with humiliation, and were expelled from Medina.
text.113:
The Jews are a people who possess evil characteristics and deeds, including disbelief in the verses of Allah, killing prophets without just cause, but they are not all the same. Among them are those who believe, even though most of them are transgressors (fasiq).

Abdullah bin Salam, Sa'labah bin Sa'id, Usaid bin 'Ubaid and their companions were Jews from the People of the Book who upheld truth and justice, did not oppress people, embraced Islam, and did not violate the commands of Allah.

They recited the verses of the Qur'an diligently and attentively during the night, starting from sunset and ending at dawn, when people were sound asleep, and they also prostrated, establishing a direct connection with Allah swt.
text.114:
They believe in Allah and in the Last Day with a sincere faith, a faith unmixed with hypocrisy. Believing in Allah also means believing in what must be believed and trusted, encompassing the pillars of faith such as belief in angels, the messengers, the heavenly books, *qada* and *qadar*, and so on.

Believing in the Last Day means avoiding all kinds of disobedience, because they are certain that if they commit disobedience in the world, they will be punished in the Hereafter, and they perform good deeds hoping for reward and the pleasure of Allah.

After perfecting themselves with good qualities and deeds as mentioned above, they also strive to save others from error, guiding them to the path of goodness through *amar makruf* (enjoining good), and preventing them from actions prohibited by religion through *nahi mungkar* (forbidding evil).

Furthermore, they collectively and competitively engage in various good deeds. Because they possess noble qualities and good deeds as mentioned, Allah includes them among the righteous.
text.115:
The Jews who remained wicked constantly provoked their friends who had believed and entered Islam, saying that they would suffer loss because of their faith.

As an answer and refutation of their evil actions, it is affirmed that whatever good deeds have been done by those who have believed, they will still receive the reward for their deeds and will not be prevented in the slightest from receiving it.

Allah is All-Knowing of those who truly believe and are pious among them. Therefore, their good deeds will not be wasted but will be rewarded manifold.
text.116:
This verse was revealed concerning the Jews and the polytheists who constantly reviled and insulted the Prophet Muhammad ﷺ, as well as his followers. They said, "If Muhammad and his followers are truly righteous and trustworthy, why are they always in poverty and destitution, while we are rich and have many children?"

They always boasted about this to the believers and tried to entice them to side with them and return to the religion of their ancestors. This was a common practice of the disbelievers in the past towards the prophets sent by Allah, as mentioned in His word:

"And they say, 'We are more (than you) in wealth and children, and we will not be punished.'" (Saba/34:35).

Therefore, as an answer to this insult and challenge, this verse was revealed, affirming that abundant wealth and children will not save them from punishment in the Hereafter.
text.117:
The parable of the wealth they spend is like a freezing wind that blows fiercely, destroying all the crops that are planted, so that the owner cannot reap even a little of the harvest. Although outwardly they have spent their wealth for the public good, such as building fortresses, bridges, schools, hospitals, and so on, with the great hope that their good deeds will be rewarded by Allah and will help them in the Hereafter, that hope will be in vain. Allah says:

"And We will proceed to what they have done of deeds and make them as dust dispersed." (al-Furqan/25:23).

"But those who disbelieve - their deeds are like a mirage in a lowland which a thirsty one thinks is water until, when he comes to it, he finds it is nothing." (an-Nur/24:39).

Actually, Allah does not wrong the disbelievers by not giving rewards for their good deeds, but they wrong themselves because they do not want to believe, even though there is much evidence in their hands that shows the truth and the prophethood of Prophet Muhammad saw.

According to scientific studies, one of the important phenomena that occurs in plants exposed to very cold air (wind) is the phenomenon of cell damage, especially leaf cells. As is generally known, approximately 70% of the cell content is water. When exposed to very cold air, the water inside the cells freezes. When water freezes, ice crystals form, which have a larger volume than water. This freezing causes the cell walls to be destroyed because they are eroded by water molecules that expand due to freezing. The appearance of this phenomenon from the outside: the leaves appear to be dry as if burned. This phenomenon often occurs in tea plants in the mountains of West Java, known as the Ibun Bajra (Fire Dew) phenomenon. The parable of wealth spent not in accordance with the will of Allah will bring destruction to the perpetrators, like cell fluid that destroys itself when exposed to cold air.

In the verse above, the consequences of changes in weather behavior on life are also shown, in this case, agricultural crops. Biologically, an unusual change in weather, for example, a sharp increase or decrease in temperature, will greatly disrupt the metabolic processes of plants. The result is clear, namely that there will be dysfunction of the various organs that exist, resulting in abnormal growth, or the plant will die.
text.118:
A warning to the believers not to associate closely with the disbelievers who have manifested their bad characteristics, not to trust them, and not to entrust the affairs of the Muslims to them. This verse is concluded with the statement, "Indeed, We have explained the verses to you so that you may understand," so that the believers truly understand and are aware of the bad characteristics of the disbelievers, and therefore it is not appropriate for them to be close friends as long as they behave badly towards the believers.

Believers should not take disbelievers as trusted friends who possess the characteristics stated in this verse, namely:

a. They constantly harm and disadvantage Muslims and try to destroy them.

b. They openly express with their tongues anger and hatred towards the Muslims, deny the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) and the Qur'an, and accuse Muslims of being ignorant and fanatical.

c. The hatred and anger they express with their tongues is very little compared to the hatred and anger hidden in their hearts. But if those characteristics have changed into good characteristics or they no longer have bad characteristics towards the Muslims, then Allah does not forbid associating with them.

Allah says:

"Allah does not forbid you from those who do not fight you because of religion and do not expel you from your homes - from being righteous toward them and acting justly toward them. Indeed, Allah loves those who act justly. Allah only forbids you from those who fight you because of religion and expel you from your homes and aid in your expulsion - [forbids] that you make allies of them. And whoever makes allies of them - then it is those who are the wrongdoers." (al-Mumtahanah/60:8-9).

Many important events related to the People of the Book are found in history, such as the betrayal of the Jewish Banu Qainuqa, Banu Nadhir and Banu Quraidhah in Yasrib against the Prophet and the Muslims, leading to the Battle of Khandaq. Then there were the Christians who helped the Muslims in the Islamic struggle, such as in the conquest of Spain and the liberation of Egypt. They expelled the Romans with the help of the Copts. Many Christians were also appointed as employees in government offices during the time of Umar bin Khattab and during the Umayyad and Abbasid dynasties, and some of them were even appointed as ambassadors representing the Islamic government.

Thus, Allah has explained His verses to the Muslims so that they may pay close attention to them, and not fall into the abyss of destruction due to carelessness and lack of vigilance when befriending the disbelievers.
text.119:
This verse adds further explanation regarding the reasons why disbelievers should not be taken as close friends, namely:

1. They dislike the success of the Muslims and desire that Muslims always be in difficulty and hardship, even though they have been considered as brothers and have been given the same rights as the Muslims themselves.

2. Muslims believe in all the Books revealed to the prophets, so there is no reason for them to hate the People of the Book because many Muslims are fond of them and associate with them well. But they still do not like the Muslims and even still have the desire to harm them.

3. Many of them are hypocrites; when facing Muslims, they utter sweet words as if they are truly genuine friends, believing in the truth of the religion brought by the Prophet Muhammad (saw), but when they return to their own group, they behave differently and openly express their hatred and anger towards the Muslims.

They even bite their fingers out of envy seeing the Muslims remain united, in agreement, and always successful in facing the enemies of Islam.

Therefore, Allah commands the Prophet Muhammad (saw) to firmly say to them:

"Die in your rage!" Indeed, Allah is Knowing of that within the breasts. (Ali 'Imran/3:119).

Allah knows all the intentions stored in the hearts of the Muslims who love those disbelievers, just as He knows the evil within the hearts of the disbelievers. So He will reward the goodness of the Muslims' hearts with manifold rewards and will also repay the evil of the disbelievers with a fitting recompense.
text.120:
Apart from the aforementioned characteristics that cause the prohibition for Muslims to take them as close friends, this verse reiterates an attitude that illustrates how evil the hearts of the disbelievers are and how intense the envious nature that blossoms in their chests. Allah says:

"If good befalls you, it grieves them; but if evil overtakes you, they rejoice at it." (Ali 'Imran/3:120).

Qatadah said in explaining this verse of Allah, as narrated by Ibn Jarir, "When the disbelievers see a strong unity among the Muslims and they achieve victory over the enemies of Islam, they feel envious and angry. But when there is division and discord among the Muslims and they experience weakness in a battle, they feel happy and joyful. Indeed, it has become *sunnatullah* (the way of Allah), both in the past until the present and in the future until the Day of Judgment, that if an intellectual arises among the disbelievers as a challenger to the religion of Islam, Allah will still reveal his falsehood, paralyze his arguments, and expose his flaws and defects."

Therefore, Allah commands the Muslims, in facing the cunning and evil intentions of the disbelievers, to always be patient, pious, and put their trust in Him. Thus, their cunning will not harm them in the slightest. Allah is All-Knowing of all their actions.
text.121: The hypocrites incited the Muslims not to participate in the war. On the way to the battlefield, they succeeded in bringing back to Medina a third of the army that had been prepared to face the polytheists. Thanks to the help of Allah, the steadfastness of heart and patience in facing all trials, and obedience and compliance in carrying out the commands of the Messenger of Allah (saw) who had divided the Muslim army into several parts and placed them in strategic positions on the battlefield. As a result of that obedience, the Muslims were able to avoid destruction.
text.122:
In that difficult and unfavorable atmosphere, there were two groups among the Muslims who almost lost their spirit after learning that three hundred people from the Muslim army refused to fight and had returned to Medina. Those who almost lost their spirit were Bani Salamah from the Khazraj tribe and Bani Haritsah from the Aus tribe, on the right and left wings respectively.

They were influenced by the very worrying atmosphere and felt that rather than being destroyed by such a large enemy, it was better to retreat. Fortunately, that feeling of discouragement did not affect them for long because they were people full of reliance on Allah and remained convinced that Allah would not waste His servants who are patient and fear Him.
text.123:
As a means of strengthening the soul and steadfastness of heart in facing all dangers and difficulties, Allah reminds them of the Battle of Badr when they were in a state of weakness and a very small number compared to the strength and number of the enemy.

Thanks to Allah's help, they succeeded in devastating the enemy until many of the Quraysh leaders fell victim and many were taken prisoner, and no small amount of spoils were obtained by the Muslims. This was because they remembered Allah's command that they be patient and fear Him (taqwa), and through patience and taqwa they would receive help from Him and achieve victory.
text.124:
To further strengthen the hearts and resolve of the Muslims in facing the Battle of Uhud, the Prophet told them that they would be aided by Allah with 3,000 angels. If they were patient and steadfast in the face of all dangers and were God-fearing, Allah would help them with 5,000 angels.

According to the narration of Adh-ahhak, this assistance with 5,000 angels was a promise from Allah that He promised to Muhammad if the Muslims were patient and God-fearing. Ibn Zaid narrated that when the Muslims saw the large number of the polytheists' army and their complete preparations, they asked the Messenger of Allah (saw), "In this Battle of Uhud, will Allah not help us as He helped us in the Battle of Badr?" Then this verse was revealed.

Indeed, in the Battle of Badr, Allah had helped the Muslims with 1000 angels, as mentioned in His word:

(Remember) when you sought help of your Lord, and He answered you, "Indeed, I will reinforce you with a thousand from the angels, following one another." (al-Anfal/8:9).

Initially, in the Battle of Uhud, the Muslim forces were able to disrupt the enemy, so that many of the polytheists fled in disarray, leaving behind their possessions, and the Islamic army began to scramble to take these possessions as *ghanimah* (spoils of war). Seeing this situation, the archers were ordered by the Prophet Muhammad (saw) to remain in their positions, no matter what happened. Thinking that the polytheists had been defeated, the archers left their positions and went down to join in taking the *ghanimah*.

Because that place had been abandoned by the archers, Khalid bin Walid, the commander of the Quraysh polytheists at that time, with his cavalry, ascended to that place and occupied it, then showered the Muslims with arrows from behind, causing chaos and panic among the Muslims. In that chaotic situation, the polytheists tried to approach the Prophet's (saw) headquarters, but the companions were able to defend it, even though the Prophet himself was injured in the face, his lips, and his teeth were broken.

Finally, thanks to their loyalty in defending the Prophet and their persistence in maintaining their position, they, along with the Prophet, climbed back up to Mount Uhud safely. Thus, the battle ended, and the polytheists returned to Mecca with a feeling of disappointment because they could not defeat Muhammad and his army, even though they themselves were still safe from destruction.
text.125:
To further strengthen the hearts and resolve of the Muslims in facing the Battle of Uhud, the Prophet told them that they would be aided by Allah with 3,000 angels. If they were patient and steadfast in facing all dangers and were pious, Allah would help them with 5,000 angels.

According to the narration of Adh-ahhak, the assistance with 5,000 angels was a promise from Allah that He promised to Muhammad if the Muslims were patient and pious. Ibn Zaid narrated that when the Muslims saw the large number of the polytheists' army and their complete preparations, they asked the Messenger of Allah (saw), "In this Battle of Uhud, will Allah not help us as He helped us in the Battle of Badr?" Then this verse was revealed.

Indeed, in the Battle of Badr, Allah had helped the Muslims with 1000 angels as mentioned in His word:

(Remember) when you sought help of your Lord, and He answered you, "Indeed, I will reinforce you with a thousand from the angels, following one another." (al-Anfal/8:9).

Initially, in the Battle of Uhud, the Muslim forces were able to disrupt the enemy, so that many of the polytheists fled in disarray, leaving behind their possessions, and the Islamic soldiers began to scramble to take these possessions as *ghanimah* (spoils of war). Seeing this situation, the archers were ordered by the Prophet Muhammad (saw) to remain in their positions, no matter what happened. Thinking that the polytheists had been defeated, the archers left their positions and went down to join in taking the *ghanimah*.

Because that place had been abandoned by the archers, Khalid bin Walid, the commander of the Quraysh polytheists at that time, with his cavalry, ascended to that place and occupied it, then showered the Muslims with arrows from behind, causing chaos and panic among the Muslims. In that chaotic situation, the polytheists tried to approach the Prophet's (saw) headquarters, but the companions were able to defend it, even though the Prophet himself was injured in the face, his lips, and his teeth were broken.

Finally, thanks to their loyalty in defending the Prophet and their persistence in maintaining their position, they, together with the Prophet, ascended back to the hill of Uhud safely. Thus, the battle ended, and the polytheists returned to Mecca with a feeling of disappointment because they could not defeat Muhammad and his army, even though they themselves were still safe from destruction.
text.126:
Whatever happens, victory truly only comes from Allah, the All-Powerful and All-Wise. So, if the Muslims truly practice the guidance of Allah and His Messenger, and truly believe and are certain of attaining victory, and remain patient and have taqwa with full tawakkul, then surely Allah will grant them victory.

But in the Battle of Uhud, there was no unity of resolve and no obedience to commands, except at the beginning of the battle. This was proven by the emergence of doubt in the hearts of two groups of Muslims and the descent of the archer troops who were ordered not to leave their posts. This is why the Muslims were severely struck in the Battle of Uhud.
text.127:
At the beginning of the battle, as mentioned above, the Muslim forces were able to disrupt the enemy lines, causing many of them to fall as casualties. Some historians say that eighteen people were killed from the polytheists.

However, this opinion is rejected by some other historians. They said, "Sayidina Hamzah alone was able to kill dozens of them." Other historians say that the reason for this difference of opinion is because when the Muslims counted the casualties among the polytheists, they only found eighteen corpses.

In fact, before returning to Mecca, the polytheists had buried some of the victims and taken others with them. So the victory of the Muslims in this first battle was thanks to their determination and steadfastness, which was caused by the words of the Prophet Muhammad (saw) mentioned in verses 124 and 125.

The defeat of the polytheists and the large number of casualties among them was indeed Allah's will to destroy a group of disbelievers, irritate their hearts, and humiliate them with that defeat.
text.128: In the second battle, the Muslims suffered a setback, resulting in 70 of them falling as *syuhada* (martyrs) and the Prophet himself sustaining injuries. This greatly saddened the hearts of the Muslims and the heart of the Prophet himself.
text.129: Indeed, such is the right of Allah over His servants, for He is the One who possesses all that is in the heavens and the earth. He has full power over everything; no one has power over His creation except Him. He is the One who punishes and decides all matters. He has the right to forgive and accept the repentance of His servants who appear disobedient, but who knows that within that servant there may be seeds of faith and goodness. He has the right to punish because He is the All-Knowing of who among His servants deserves punishment in this world or the hereafter. In addition to that, Allah is the Most Forgiving, the Most Merciful.
text.130:
This verse is the first revealed regarding the prohibition of riba (interest/usury). The verses concerning the prohibition of riba in Surah al-Baqarah verses 275, 276, and 278 were revealed after this verse. The riba in this verse is *riba nasiah*, also called *riba jahiliah*, which was commonly practiced by people at that time.

Ibn Jarir said, "What Allah intends in this verse is: O you who believe in Allah and His Messenger, do not consume riba multiplied repeatedly, as you did during the time of *jahiliah* after you entered Islam, even though you have been guided by Him." At that time, if someone borrowed money as agreed upon when borrowing, the lender would demand that the debt be repaid according to the agreed-upon time. The borrower (because they did not have the money to pay) would request a postponement and promise to pay with a specified addition. Every time the payment was delayed, the interest was added again. This is what is called *riba* multiplied repeatedly, and Allah forbids Muslims from doing such a thing.

Ar-Razi provides the following explanation: "If someone owes another person one hundred dirhams and the time to pay the debt has arrived, but the debtor is unable to pay, the creditor allows the postponement of the debt payment, provided that the debtor is willing to make the debt two hundred dirhams or double it. Then, when the payment time arrives and the debtor is still unable to pay, the payment can be postponed with the condition that the debt is multiplied again, and so on, until the debt becomes piled up. This is what is meant by the word "multiplied repeatedly" in Allah's word. This type of *riba* is also called *riba nasiah* because of the postponement in payment, not cash."

In addition to *riba nasiah*, there is also *riba* called *riba fadhal*, which is exchanging goods of the same type but of different quality, for example, exchanging 1 liter of high-quality rice for 1Â½ liters of low-quality rice. The prohibition of *riba fadhal* is based on the hadith of the Prophet, and only applies to gold, silver, and staple foods, or what is termed "ribawi goods."

Because of the severity of the law of *riba* and its great danger, Allah commands Muslims to avoid *riba* and always protect themselves and be pious to Allah so that they do not fall into it and so that they can live happily and prosperously in this world and in the hereafter.
text.131:
Allah commands the Muslims to safeguard themselves and distance themselves from the actions of the disbelievers who do not care whether the wealth they acquire comes from unlawful sources such as usury (riba), exploiting the weak and the poor, and so on. All unlawful means will endanger them in this world and lead them to Hell in the Hereafter.

Explained by Imam Abu Hanifah, that this verse contains a very frightening threat, because in this verse Allah threatens to put the Muslims into the Hell that is prepared for the disbelievers if they do not protect themselves from the actions that He has forbidden.
text.132: Then, that command is followed by a command for the Muslims to always be obedient and compliant to the commands of Allah and His Messenger because by obeying Allah and His Messenger, they will be able to receive an abundance of His mercy and be able to live happily in this world and the hereafter.
text.133:
Allah commands the Muslims to hasten to seek forgiveness from Him whenever they commit sins and transgressions, because humans are not free from mistakes and errors. A Muslim would not willingly commit forbidden acts, but sometimes due to the strength of temptation and the deception of Satan, he falls into the abyss of transgression. Then, when he realizes his mistake and regrets his actions, he repents and asks Allah for forgiveness, then Allah will forgive his sins. Allah is the Most Accepting of Repentance, the Most Forgiving, and the Most Merciful.

If a Muslim always obeys the commands of Allah and His Messenger and avoids all His prohibitions, and immediately repents if he falls into the abyss of sin and transgression, then Allah will forgive his sins and will admit him in the Hereafter into a vast Paradise as a reward for the deeds he has done in the world, namely the Paradise that He has prepared for the righteous (muttaqin).
text.134:
This verse directly explains the characteristics of the pious: First: Those who always spend their wealth, both in times of ease and in times of hardship (poverty), according to their ability. Spending wealth is not required in a fixed amount, so there is an opportunity for the poor to give. Giving charity can be done with goods or money of little value, because whatever is given will still receive a reward from Allah SWT.

It is narrated by Aisyah Ummul Mukminin that she gave a single grape as charity, and among the companions of the Prophet, some gave a single onion. It is narrated that the Messenger of Allah SAW said:

"Protect yourselves from the fire of hell even by giving half a date in charity, and grant the request of a beggar even by giving a piece of burnt animal hoof." (Narrated by Ahmad in his Musnad).

For the rich and affluent, of course, charity and generosity must be adjusted to their ability. It is very strange and even embarrassing if someone with abundant wealth only gives charity and donations in the same amount as the poor. This shows that the awareness of spending has not been instilled in their hearts. Allah says:

Let the rich man spend according to his means; and whoever has his means of subsistence straitened, let him spend out of that which Allah has given him. Allah does not burden any human being with more than He has given him. After hardship, Allah will bring about ease. (ath-Thalaq/65:7).

The stinginess that is ingrained in the human heart must be eradicated by all means and efforts, because this trait is public enemy number one. No nation can advance and live happily if this stinginess prevails in that nation. Stinginess is contrary to humanity.

Therefore, Allah commands us to spend and explains that wealth for which zakat is paid and part of which is given in charity will not decrease but will increase. Allah says:

Allah destroys interest and gives increase for charities. (al-Baqarah/2:276).

Imam Ghazali explains that fighting a bad trait must be done by getting used to fighting that trait. So, if a person wants to eradicate stinginess in themselves, they should get used to giving charity and helping others. By getting used to it, stinginess will gradually disappear.

Second: Those who restrain their anger. Usually, people who indulge their anger cannot control their minds and will commit cruel and evil acts, so that when they realize it, they will definitely regret the actions they took and they will be surprised why they acted so far. Therefore, when someone is angry, they should try as hard as possible to restrain their anger first. When they have regained control and their anger has begun to subside, then they can take fair action in response to the treatment of others towards them.

If a person has trained themselves like that, then they will not take actions that are excessive, even they will consider that unfair treatment towards them may be due to mistakes and unintentional and they will forgive it. Allah explains that restraining anger is a path to piety. People who are truly pious will definitely be able to control themselves when they are angry.

Siti Aisyah once became angry because of the actions of her servant, but she was able to control herself, because of the piety that was in her. She said, "How good is piety, it can be a cure for all anger." Prophet Muhammad SAW said, "The strong person is not the one who can wrestle his opponent but the truly strong person is the one who can restrain his anger." Allah says:

... And when they are angry, they forgive. (asy-Syura/42:37).

Third: Those who forgive the mistakes of others. Forgiving the mistakes of others when we are able to repay them with an equal reward is a good trait that every Muslim must have. This may be difficult to practice because it has become a habit for humans to repay evil with evil, but for humans who have high morals and strong faith and whose souls have been filled with piety, forgiving mistakes is easy for them.

Perhaps repaying evil with evil is still within the framework of justice, but it must be realized that repaying evil with evil also cannot eradicate or eliminate evil. Perhaps with the existence of retaliation, evil will spread and develop.

If evil is repaid with forgiveness and then followed by good deeds, then the person who commits the evil will realize that they have committed a very bad and unfair act towards someone who is pure of heart and likes to do good. Thus, they will not do it again and the door to evil will be closed.

Fourth: Those who do good. Doing good is a characteristic of the pious, so in addition to forgiving the mistakes of others, forgiveness should be accompanied by doing good to the person who made the mistake.

Narrated by al-Baihaqi, there was a *jariah* (female slave) belonging to Ali bin Husain who helped her master pour water from a jug to perform ablution. Then the jug fell from her hand and broke into pieces. Then Ali bin Husain looked at her face as if he was angry. The slave said, "Allah says:

... And those who restrain anger ... (Ali 'Imran/3:134)."

Ali bin Husain replied, "I have restrained that anger." Then the slave said again, "Allah says:

... And pardon (the faults) of the people ... (Ali 'Imran/3:134)."

Ali bin Husain answered, "I have forgiven you." Finally, the slave said again, "Allah says:

... And Allah loves those who do good. (Ali 'Imran/3:134)."

Ali bin Husain replied, "Go, I have freed you," for the sake of achieving the pleasure of Allah.

Such was the action of one of the grandchildren of the Prophet Muhammad SAW towards the mistake of a slave because he was indeed a pious believer, not only did he forgive his slave's mistake, but he also accompanied the forgiveness with doing good to him by freeing him.
text.135:
Those who commit indecency or wrong themselves, then quickly seek forgiveness from Allah and do not repeat the act.

The commentators of the Quran (mufasir) distinguish between indecent acts (fahisyah) and wronging oneself (dhulm). They say that indecent acts are those whose harm not only befalls the sinner but also affects others and society. Wronging oneself is committing a sin whose harm is only felt by the person who commits it. Indecent acts include adultery, gambling, slander, and so on. Wronging oneself includes eating forbidden foods, wasting wealth, squandering it, and so on.

Perhaps a Muslim inadvertently commits a major sin because of weak faith, because of the temptation of Satan, or for other reasons, but he immediately realizes and regrets his actions, then he asks forgiveness from Allah and repents with a sincere repentance and promises himself not to do it again. Then Allah will accept his repentance and forgive his sins because Allah is the Acceptor of Repentance and the Most Forgiving.

If a person commits a sin, even if it is not a major sin, but commits it continuously without any awareness of wanting to stop it and without regret or a desire to repent to Allah, then that sin becomes a major sin. The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) once said:

"A major sin does not remain a major sin if one quickly seeks forgiveness (from Allah). And a minor sin will become a major sin if it is always committed." (Narrated by ad-Dailami from Ibn Abbas).

Seeking forgiveness from Allah is not just uttering the words "I seek forgiveness from Allah," but must be accompanied by regret and a promise to oneself not to commit that sin again. This is what is called *taubat nasuha*, a repentance that is accepted by Allah.
text.136:
Thus are five characteristics among the characteristics of those who are pious (taqwa) to Allah that every Muslim should possess. Every Muslim should strive to embody these five characteristics perfectly because by possessing them, they will become a Muslim who can benefit themselves and also benefit others, their society, nation, and country.

Those who possess these characteristics will be rewarded by Allah with forgiveness of their sins and will be placed in Paradise in the Hereafter. They will abide therein forever, and indeed that is the best reward for everyone who does good deeds and strives to improve themselves, their society, and their ummah.
text.137:
Allah's Sunnah or Sunnatullah means the prevailing decree that the truth will ultimately prevail and falsehood will be defeated. In general, this verse is still within the framework of the description of the Battle of Uhud (which began from verse 121). Regarding the important events and the attitude of the disbelievers towards the believers, which ended with the victory of the believers, thanks to their faith and patience in facing all kinds of dangers and obstacles to defend and uphold the truth.

Sunnatullah (the prevailing decree) towards His creatures in the form of glory or decline, never changes and is always repeated or occurs in every people who are in the same causes. Thus, since the ancient peoples before the people of Muhammad, it still applies today. Therefore, we are guided to travel and investigate the earth, so that we conclude that Allah in His decree has linked the cause with its effect. For example, if someone wants to be rich, then he must strive for the causes that can bring wealth. If you want to win in war, you must prepare all the causes to obtain victory, both in terms of material and tactics, and so on. If you want to be happy in this world and the hereafter, do the causes to obtain it, and so on.

Verse 137 commands us to investigate and pay attention to the causes of the descent of punishment upon those who deny the truth.
text.138:
What is mentioned in verse 137 is a warning for all mankind and guidance as well as a lesson for the righteous. Tafsir scholars say that the intent of this verse is to warn the Muslims that their defeat in the Battle of Uhud was a lesson for the Islamic community, and the application of Allah's sunnah (established way/law).

They were victorious in the Battle of Badr because they carried out and obeyed the Prophet's commands. In the Battle of Uhud, they were also close to achieving victory, but because they were negligent and no longer obeyed the Prophet's commands, they were eventually surrounded and attacked from behind by enemy soldiers who were far greater in number, resulting in the martyrdom of dozens of *syuhada* (martyrs) from the Muslims, and the Prophet himself suffered injuries and had one of his teeth broken.
text.139: This verse urges Muslims not to be weak and grieve, even though they experienced a heavy blow and quite bitter suffering in the Battle of Uhud, because winning or losing in a war is a normal thing that is included in Allah's provisions. This should be taken as a lesson. Muslims in warfare actually have a strong mentality and high spirit and are superior if they truly believe.
text.140: This verse explains that if the Muslims suffer wounds or meet their death, then the disbelievers have also experienced the same in the Battle of Badr. Thus, victory and defeat in war are things that Allah alternates among people. Victory and defeat, glory and decline, are conditions that every people or human being will experience in turn. Therefore, they should always be able to take guidance from this situation, so that they may learn a lesson, and so that Allah may distinguish between those who believe and those who disbelieve, and also grant the Muslims the happiness of martyrdom (syahid) which is of very high value in the sight of Allah, because they are willing to sacrifice their lives and bodies to defend the truth, and Allah does not like those who do wrong (zalim).
text.141:
The event of the Muslims' misfortune in the Battle of Uhud, after their victory in the Battle of Badr previously, was also intended to distinguish those who truly believed from the hypocrites and to purify the hearts of the believers who were still weak, so that they would truly become sincere, free from sin.

The degree of someone's faith is still hidden, and its true nature is not clear except through severe trials. If he passes the test, then he can be said to be a pure and holy person, just as gold, its authenticity can only be known after it is refined, burned, and tested with acid.

The archer troops violated the Prophet's command ﷺ in the Battle of Uhud by leaving their positions on the mountain, then joining in seizing the spoils of war. Because of this, the Muslim troops were eventually beaten back, scattered by the enemy. This event became a lesson for the Muslims to make them aware that the Islamic ummah was not created to play around, indulge in luxury, be lazy, hoard wealth, but must be serious in doing good deeds, obeying the Prophet's commands ﷺ and not violating them, whatever may happen.

The sincerity of the Muslims' hearts and their obedience to the Prophet's commands could be proven when the Battle of Hamra al-Asad occurred after being beaten in the Battle of Uhud. The Prophet ﷺ commanded that those who were allowed to participate in the Battle of Hamra al-Asad were those who had participated in the Battle of Uhud. They gladly obeyed the Prophet's command with a sincere and willing heart, even though some of them were still experiencing severe injuries, sad and anxious hearts. Conversely, the disbelievers suffered destruction because their hearts were dirty, still harboring within them the characteristics of arrogance and pride, as a result of the victory they had obtained.
text.142:
The scholars of tafsir explain that after the Prophet (saw) learned of the Quraysh's preparations, consisting of a large army, to attack the Muslims as retaliation for their defeat in the Battle of Badr, the Prophet (saw) consulted with his companions as to whether they should remain in the city of Medina or go out to fight outside the city.

Although the Prophet himself was more inclined to remain in the city of Medina, he followed the majority opinion which desired to attack the enemy outside the city. Thus, the Messenger of Allah (saw) went out of the city to the hill of Uhud with an army of 1,000 men to fight the Quraysh who numbered more than 3,000. This much smaller Muslim army almost achieved victory, but eventually the situation reversed into failure due to a lack of patience in obeying the orders of the Messenger of Allah as commander in that battle.

Many victims fell here and there, and some fled in fear. The Prophet himself was cornered and threatened, and it was even rumored that the Prophet (saw) had been killed. Those who were killed as martyrs were his companions such as Abu Dujanah, Thalhah bin 'Ubaidillah, Ummu 'Imarah and others who had sacrificed themselves and their lives as shields for the Messenger of Allah. Hamzah bin 'Abdul Muthalib, the Prophet's beloved uncle, was also killed in the Battle of Uhud. In verse 142, Allah says, "Do you think that you will enter Paradise before Allah has made evident those of you who fight in His cause and made evident those who are steadfast?"

This is a rebuke and correction from God to some of the Muslims who participated in the Battle of Uhud, namely to those who initially wanted to fight with fiery enthusiasm and encouraged the Messenger of Allah to go out of the city to fight the Quraysh and not just stay in the city of Medina. They firmly stated that they were able to do anything to face the enemy even if they would die like the heroes of Badr. But in reality, after they were in a difficult and critical situation, not only did they lose their enthusiasm and were unable to carry out what they had previously stated to the Messenger of Allah, but most of them had lost their footing, except for some whose fighting spirit and struggle continued to burn brightly, because of the steadfastness of their conviction and faith that could not be shaken by any circumstances or situation. These were the defenders of the Messenger of Allah, the defenders of Islam and the truth.
text.143: Before the Battle of Uhud, the Muslims promised to die as martyrs, following in the footsteps of the martyrs of Badr. But they did not keep that promise when they saw the ferocity of the battle. As the culmination of the difficulties faced by the Muslims in the Battle of Uhud, the news spread that the Messenger of Allah had been killed. At that time, those with weak faith wanted to obtain favors from 'Abdullah bin Ubai, the head of the hypocrites in Medina, so that he would try to obtain protection from Abu Sufyan. Some even shouted, saying, "If Muhammad is dead, let us return to our original religion." In that chaotic situation, a companion of the Prophet (Anas bin an-Nadhar) spoke, "Even if Muhammad has been killed, the Lord of Muhammad will not be killed. Why should you live after the death of the Messenger of Allah? Let us continue to fight, even though he has died." Then Anas bin an-Nadhar prayed for forgiveness from God for the words of those with weak faith, then he took his sword and continued to fight until he died as a martyr.
text.144:
Muhammad is only a Messenger of Allah. If he dies or is killed, that is a normal occurrence, as has also happened to the prophets and messengers before him. Some died naturally, and some were killed. Why are some Muslims turning away from their faith upon hearing the news that Muhammad has died or been killed? Know that those who turn away will not cause any harm to Allah. And Allah will reward those who are grateful to Him. The meaning of being grateful is usually interpreted as thankfulness. Thankfulness in this verse is not merely a verbal expression, but through actions and concrete evidence.

Being grateful to humans means doing good to them as a reciprocation, while being grateful to Allah means being devoted to Him, in accordance with His commands. In upholding the truth, we must strive earnestly, struggle with full faith and patience, and be willing to accept all kinds of trials and suffering. Such people are the ones who are truly grateful to Allah and who will certainly receive the reward He has promised.
text.145:
Allah states, "And no soul will die except by permission of Allah at a decree determined." Meaning: the matter of death is only in the hands of God, not in anyone's hands or in the hands of the enemy that is feared. This is a rebuke to the believers who fled the battlefield of the Battle of Uhud for fear of death, and it is also guidance for every Muslim who is struggling in the path of Allah. Furthermore, Allah gives guidance to Muslims on how they should struggle in the path of Allah with His word:

... Whoever desires the reward of this world - We will give him thereof; (Ali 'Imran/3:145).

This means that every Muslim must straighten and correct his intention in carrying out every struggle. If his intention is only to obtain worldly rewards, then no matter how great his struggle, the reward will only be worldly. And whoever intends to obtain the reward of the Hereafter, then Allah will reward him with the reward of the Hereafter. Allah will reward those who are grateful, namely those who obey His commands and always accompany His Prophet.
text.146: Allah again provides correction to some of the followers of Prophet Muhammad saw who were weak and unfaithful in the Battle of Uhud by presenting the circumstances of the communities of previous prophets, that in jihad fisabilillah, their spirit and faith remained strong, not weak, not lethargic, and did not surrender when suffering calamity. Such people are the ones loved by Allah because of their patience.
text.147: Besides their patience and steadfastness in striving in the path of Allah (jihad fisabilillah) alongside the Prophet, they did not forget to establish a direct connection with Allah SWT by praying that their sins and excessive actions be forgiven by God, and that their resolve be strengthened so that they would be victorious over the disbelievers.
text.148: Due to the sincerity, devotion, steadfastness of faith, and patience of the followers of the previous prophets in facing all kinds of suffering in striving for truth in the path of Allah, Allah gave them worldly rewards and a commensurate reward in the Hereafter.
text.149:
According to Ali bin Abi Talib, this verse was revealed in connection with the event of the believers when they suffered a heavy blow in the Battle of Uhud, so the hypocrites said to them, "Return to your brothers and embrace their religion." Thus, what is meant by the disbelievers in this verse are the hypocrites.

This verse warns every believer in Allah, whether they have experienced suffering in the Battle of Uhud or others in every time and place, to always be vigilant so as not to fall into a weak attitude, surrender, and follow the poisonous persuasion of the disbelievers, hypocrites, and Jews, because the consequences will cause very great danger and loss.
text.150: Muslims are urged to obey Allah because He is their best Protector. They should not follow the disbelievers like Abu Sufyan and his companions (at that time), or the hypocrites like 'Abdullah bin Ubai or other disbelievers and hypocrites who will mislead them and plunge them into a very dangerous abyss.
text.151:
The form of Allah's help given to the believers is by whispering into the hearts of the disbelievers a fear to continue the war, because they associate partners with Allah. Their place is Hell, and that is the worst abode for the wrongdoers.

Indeed, no matter how great and mighty someone is, they will feel weak and unable to do anything if they are overcome by fear.
text.152:
Allah has fulfilled all that He promised to His believing servants, where they reached a stage of victory by destroying the enemy's forces, which were far greater in number and preparation. However, because they lacked patience, obedience, and discipline towards Muhammad's command, which ordered every squad, especially the archer squad, not to leave their respective positions before receiving an order, many of them violated it. They even disagreed because they desired worldly possessions, namely pursuing war spoils. Consequently, what happened, happened: the enemy became strong again because they had seized strategic positions, ultimately weakening the Muslims, who then suffered due to their own actions and behavior, as a test from Allah of their faith, patience, and discipline.

At the end of this verse, Allah explains what had happened, and they regretted those mistakes. Allah has forgiven them because Allah always bestows His favor upon the believers.

The scholars of *tafsir* elaborate on what is meant by Allah's promise mentioned in this verse as follows:

1.  Allah's promise to help the believers in the Battle of Uhud by sending reinforcements of five thousand angels, if they were patient and God-fearing.

2.  Allah's promise to grant victory conveyed by the Prophet to the archer squad as long as they did not leave their positions. But apparently, many left their positions.

3.  Allah's promise to help every believer who is patient and God-fearing, which is mentioned many times in several verses and *surahs* in the Al-Qur'an.

If we observe the three opinions above, they are not contradictory to one another; they only differ in their perspective. The first opinion views it from a historical perspective and the relationship of verse 152 to verse 125.
