The second opinion views it from the historical reality of their violation of the war tactics that the Rasulullah had ordered them to follow. The third opinion views it generally, because in the Al-Qur'an, there are many verses that promise help and assistance to those who believe, are patient, and are God-fearing towards Him.
text.153: Important events in the ranks of the Muslims during the Battle of Uhud, namely: the reasons for their failure, when most of them fled, while the Messenger called them from behind not to do so and to return to their respective troops, but they did not heed him. Therefore, they suffered quite severely. If they had realized what they had done at that time, they certainly would not have been saddened or surprised why they failed in the Battle of Uhud. Allah is All-Knowing of all that they would do.
text.154:
Following the events after they experienced hardship and suffering, Allah bestowed upon a group of them, those strong in faith and patient, a feeling of drowsiness to calm them from fear, fatigue, and anxiety. Thus, they could regain their strength, which had diminished due to the intensity of the battle and loss of morale. Meanwhile, another group did not receive this blessing of drowsiness, namely those weak in faith, who remained fearful and anxious. This verse states that the followers of the Prophet, after the battle, were divided into two groups.

First: The group that realized their setback in the Battle of Uhud was due to their mistake of lacking discipline towards the command of the Messenger of Allah as the commander of the battle. They remained convinced and believed in Allah's help in the form of victory for those who believe. Because even though they experienced disaster this time, Allah would still defend those who believe. It was this group that received the blessing of drowsiness.

Second: The group that was weak in faith because they were filled with worry, they were not so sure of the command of the Messenger of Allah because of the hypocrisy that had taken root in their hearts. It was this second group that suspected the worst of Allah and Muhammad, like the suspicions of the people of ignorance (jahiliyyah). Among other things, they suspected that if Muhammad was truly a Prophet and Messenger, then he and his companions would not have been defeated in the Battle of Uhud. They said to absolve themselves of responsibility, "Do we have any say in this matter?" Say, O Muhammad, "Indeed, all matters are in the hand of Allah."

They conceal much that they do not reveal to you, saying, "If we had any say in the matter, we would not have been killed here." But say to them, even if they had remained in their homes without participating in the battle, if it was destined for them to die outside their homes, then they would surely have died in the place that had been determined. All these events are to test what is stored in the chests of the Muslims and to cleanse their hearts from the doubts whispered by Satan, so that faith in their hearts becomes stronger. Allah is All-Knowing of what is in their hearts.
text.155:
During the decisive battle of the Battle of Uhud, some Muslims left the defensive position that should not have been abandoned, especially by the archers, but they left it anyway. They felt the enemy had been defeated, so they left their positions intending to obtain spoils of war. Eventually, the enemy occupied their positions, and they were scattered and suffered from relentless enemy attacks. Nevertheless, they eventually realized and regretted their mistake, so Allah forgave them. Indeed, Allah is Most Forgiving and Most Forbearing by freeing them from punishment in the hereafter.

No war in Islamic history during the Prophet's time was ever initiated by the Muslims. The attitude of the Prophet and his companions in this matter was only defensive, self-defense, not offensive, in accordance with the principles in the Al-Qur'an, "Fight in the way of Allah those who fight you but do not transgress. Indeed. Allah does not like transgressors." (al-Baqarah/2: 190). But if the enemy inclines towards peace, then incline to it [also] (al-Anfal/8: 61). We must always be ready to accept peace if the tendency towards peace on the other side is also the same. Our task must be to be pioneers of peace, not pioneers of war. There is no benefit in fighting just for the sake of fighting.

That is what happened in the Battle of Badr (Ali 'Imran/3: 13, 123) in the month of Ramadan in the second year after the Hijrah. Then in the Battle of Ahzab (Battle of the Trench, al-Ahzab/33:9) around the 5th year after the Hijrah, the polytheists of Mecca with a force of 10,000 people, with the help of the Jews who betrayed after making an agreement with the Messenger of Allah. But they then fled and returned to Mecca carrying a great failure. Then the last was the Battle of Hunain shortly after the Liberation of Mecca in the 8th year.

Likewise in the Battle of Uhud (Ali Imran/3:121) which occurred a year after the Battle of Badr, the enemy who came all the way from Mecca wanted to attack Medina. Their arrival with a force of 3000 people came to Medina to avenge their defeat in the Battle of Badr. In this war, the Muslims and the Messenger of Allah received a heavy trial.

The Prophet Saw consulted with his companions, as had become the Prophet's way of life, always consulting. Some of them wanted to stay inside the city, on the grounds that the enemy did not know the ins and outs of the city. If the enemy enters the city, we will surround and attack them. The people will also attack with stones from the roofs of houses. Others wanted to meet the enemy outside the city, because if the enemy set foot in the city of Medina, the residents would become victims, and they would consider it a victory and would make them more courageous. Based on the decision with that consideration, the Muslims set out outside the city under the leadership of the Messenger of Allah saw. In this war, there was no winner and no loser.

In facing this threat, the Messenger of Allah, with his far-sighted, courageous and responsible view, immediately decided to take a place at the foot of Mount Uhud, which surrounds most of the city of Medina, about three miles to the north. On 7 Syawal in the third year of Hijri (January 625) at dawn, he had made preparations to face the war. Medina is famous for its extraordinary winter, but the Muslim soldiers (700 to 1000 people) were ready that dawn. To their south was a steep valley with a swift stream of water, while the hill corridors behind them were occupied by 50 archers to prevent enemy attacks from behind. The enemy was preparing to attack the walls of Medina, while the Muslim forces were behind them. At first, the battle was advantageous to the Muslims. The enemy was in disarray, but the Muslim archers, who did not obey the Prophet's orders, left their posts. They joined in chasing and competing for spoils of war.

The order was: Do not chase after spoils of war, and maintain strong discipline. Not a few enemies were killed, and they had begun to retreat. At that time, some of the Muslim forces, violating orders, continued to pursue them because they were attracted by the possibility of obtaining spoils of war. The enemy took advantage of the opportunity that had been left by the archers, and that was when a very fierce one-on-one battle took place, which, according to reports, greatly benefited the enemy. Many companions from the Ansar were killed.

But they did not know how to retreat. In this battle, Hamzah, the Prophet's uncle from his father's side, was killed as a martyr. The Messenger of Allah himself also suffered injuries to his head and face, and a tooth was knocked out. If it were not for his steadfastness, courage and composure, the Muslims would have suffered a great defeat. Even though the Messenger of Allah was injured, as were the other Muslims, the next day they returned to the battlefield. Abu Sufyan and his Meccan forces carefully withdrew immediately. Medina could be saved. The Muslims can learn from this event: faith, loyalty and perseverance. (Summarized from Tafsir Al-Qur'an A. Yusuf Ali).
text.156:
Regarding the spirit of jihad already ingrained in the believers, Allah forbids them from adopting beliefs like those of the disbelievers who say about their friends who died while traveling or fighting, "If they, those believers, had stayed with us, not gone to fight, surely they would not have died and not been killed."

That belief and statement are not only untrue, but also cause deep regret, even though the matter of life and death is in the hands of Allah. He is the One who gives life and causes death to all His creatures according to the time, place, and cause that have been determined.
text.157: Then, that verse explains that there is nothing for believers to fear when they strive in the path of Allah, because if they are killed or die, they will surely obtain forgiveness and mercy from Allah. That is far better for them than spoils of war or this fleeting worldly wealth.
text.158:
Everyone will die or fall for any reason, whether dying in battle, while traveling, or in their own home. They will certainly be returned to Allah and all their deeds will be reckoned in the afterlife. If they are evil, they will be recompensed with the torment of hellfire, and if they are good, they will be recompensed with entry into paradise.

Therefore, a believer should choose and follow the path that can bring him closer to Allah, so that he may obtain His forgiveness and mercy. For this reason, a Muslim should not be reluctant to engage in *jihad* in the path of Allah, to draw closer to Him.
text.159:
Even in critical situations, such as the violations committed by some Muslims during the Battle of Uhud which caused the Muslims to suffer, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) remained gentle and did not become angry with those who violated the rules. Instead, he forgave them and sought forgiveness from Allah for them. If the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) had been harsh and hard-hearted, they would surely have distanced themselves from him.

In addition, the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) always consulted with them in all matters, especially in matters of warfare. Therefore, the Muslims obediently implemented the decisions of these consultations because the decisions were their own decisions together with the Prophet. They continued to struggle and strive in the path of Allah with unwavering determination, regardless of the dangers and difficulties they faced. They placed their complete trust (tawakal) in Allah, because there is no one who can defend the Muslims except Allah.
text.160: When Allah intends to help the Muslim army, nothing can prevent it, just as Allah helped the Muslim army in the Battle of Badr because they surrendered themselves to Allah. Likewise, if Allah intends to humiliate them or inflict disaster upon them, nothing can prevent it, as happened in the Battle of Uhud due to a lack of obedience and discipline towards the command of the Messenger. Therefore, every believer should put their complete trust in Allah, because there is no one who can defend the Muslims except Allah.
text.161:
In the Battle of Badr, a red blanket from the spoils of war went missing before it was distributed. Some of the hypocrites said that the blanket might have been taken by the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) or the archers.

It is inappropriate and impossible for the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) to commit treachery by taking war booty (ghanimah). This contradicts the attributes of the Prophet's infallibility (being protected from reprehensible actions), his high morals which serve as the primary example. Whoever commits such treachery, on the Day of Judgment, he will come carrying the spoils of his treachery and will not hide it. Everyone will receive recompense for their deeds, good or bad, and in that recompense, they will not be wronged. Like a person who does good having their reward reduced or a person who does evil having their punishment increased.

What is meant by *gulul* in verse 161 is taking what belongs to the public in secret. So, the taking is a form of stealing. One of the characteristics of a messenger is *amanah*, trustworthiness. Therefore, it is highly unlikely that the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) would commit *gulul*. In fact, regarding the issue of *gulul*, the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) once said:

"O people! Whoever among you does something for us, then he hides a sewn item or more than that, then that action is *gulul* (corruption) and must be accounted for on the Day of Judgment." (Narrated by Muslim).

"From Umar bin al-Khattab, he said, "After the Battle of Khaibar was over, some companions came to the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) saying, 'So-and-so died as a martyr, so-and-so died as a martyr,' until they mentioned so-and-so C died as a martyr. The Prophet replied, 'No, I see so-and-so C in hell, because he stole a blanket or a piece of clothing.' Then the Prophet said, 'O Umar, go and announce to the people that so-and-so C will not enter paradise, except for the believers.' Umar said, then I went out, and I called out, 'Know that so-and-so C will not enter paradise except for the believers.'" (Narrated by Muslim).
text.162:
The person who seeks Allah's pleasure through worship and righteous deeds is not the same as the person who earns Allah's wrath by committing sins, violating His prohibitions, and neglecting his obligations. The person who earns Allah's wrath, his place is in Hell, and that is the worst place to return to.

In the Qur'an, there are many verses that are linked together mentioning two different groups whose characteristics are indeed different and opposite, for example, the verse:

"Then is one who knows that what has been revealed to you from your Lord is the truth like one who is blind?..." (ar-Rad/13:19).

"Then is one to whom We have promised a good promise [of Paradise] which he will obtain like one for whom We provided enjoyment of worldly life..." (al-Qasas/28:61).

Each of these two groups has its own levels, because on the Day of Judgment, which is the Day of Recompense, both groups will be rewarded according to their deeds in the world. Those who do much good will have a high level, and those who do much evil will be at the lowest level. The highest level of mankind is usually called *ar-rafiul ala*, which is the level reached by the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), and the lowest is called *ad-darkul asfal*. This is explained in the Qur'an that man in the sight of Allah, whether he is good or bad, has varying degrees of goodness and badness. Allah is All-Knowing of the levels of their deeds and gives rewards according to each person's deeds.
text.163:
All of Allah's visible creations are divided into 3 types: *nabatat* (plants), *hayawanat* (animals), and *jamadat* (inanimate objects).

The *nabatat* type includes all plants, whether they grow on land or in water, or in other places, such as on branches or tree trunks. The *hayawanat* type includes all living creatures with souls. The *jamadat* type includes everything other than *nabatat* and *hayawanat*. Among the *hayawanat* type, some are endowed with reason and understanding for their lives, such as humans, while others are not. Humans, by using their reason, intellect, and understanding, should be able to distinguish between good and bad, between what is beneficial and what is harmful.

Then, they can choose what is good for their own benefit. However, because humans are also given *hawa nafsu* (desires/passions), if they are not wise in controlling them, they will be more inclined towards evil and wickedness. Therefore, if humans navigate the ship of life and existence without the leadership and guidance of a messenger (rasul), they will experience chaos, destruction, and ruin.

This has been proven by the history of Prophet Adam. Meaning: in every *zaman fatrah* (a period of vacuum between one messenger and the next), humans on earth always experience chaos, turmoil, and destruction, so the sending of a messenger is a blessing and happiness for human society.
text.164: Allah has indeed bestowed benefit and blessings upon all believers in general, and upon those who believed alongside the Messenger of Allah in particular, because Allah sent a messenger from among themselves, so that they could easily understand his speech and witness his behavior to follow and emulate his deeds. Prophet Muhammad directly recited the verses of Allah's greatness, purified them in deeds and beliefs, and taught them al-Kitab and al-Hikmah. As for what is meant by al-Kitab, it is a compendium of all revealed knowledge, while al-Hikmah encompasses all acquired knowledge. If related to the existence of kalam and philosophy, then kalam leans more towards al-Kitab, while philosophy leans more towards al-Hikmah, although both glorify each other with a high degree of harmony. Both meet in the commonality of faith and the depth of religious feeling.
text.165:
This verse is still related to the verses about the story of the Battle of Uhud. During the Battle of Uhud, 70 of the Muslim army fell as martyrs (syuhada). Among them were those who asked, from where and why did we experience such a great calamity? Whereas the Muslim army in the Battle of Badr had achieved a great victory by making the enemy flee in disarray and being able to kill 70 enemies and capture 70 more.

In response to that question, the Messenger of Allah (Rasulullah) received an order to answer that the disaster was due to their own mistakes. The archer troops were ordered by the Messenger of Allah to hold their position on the hill and not to leave it before receiving an order from him. But they had violated that order and descended, leaving the hill to participate in taking spoils of war (ghanimah). From the hill that was abandoned by the archer troops, the enemy attacked the Islamic army, so that in the end they suffered defeat. Indeed, Allah is All-Powerful over all things.
text.166:
The victory obtained by the Islamic army in the Battle of Badr was due to the permission and help of Allah. On the surface, defeat is bad luck, while victory is good luck for the martyrs and a lesson for the Muslims. Allah says:

"Whatever good befalls you is from Allah, and whatever evil befalls you is from yourself..." (an-Nisa/4:79).

The existence of victory and defeat in the beginning of a war, whether for the Muslim army or the other side, is a common thing, but in the end, the Muslim army will be victorious. This is intended, among other things, to test the steadfastness of faith and the perseverance of each individual so that the faith of the believers becomes stronger, making them distinguishable from other people.
text.167:
Likewise, so that the hypocrisy of the hypocrites could be clearly known. During the Battle of Uhud, the number of Islamic soldiers was 1,000, but in the middle of the journey, 300 people belonging to the *munafiqun* under the leadership of Abdullah bin Ubay returned to Medina. Thus, the Battle of Uhud was a separator between soldiers who truly believed and those who were half-hearted in their faith, namely the hypocrites.

When the *munafiqun* were invited to fight *fi sabilillah* to uphold the religion of Allah, defend rights and justice, and reject falsehood and evil in order to seek the pleasure of Allah, or to fight to protect themselves and defend their homeland, they answered, "If we knew that we could and were able to fight, we would surely follow the Muslims." But they judged that the Muslims were fighting at that time merely throwing themselves into destruction. In reality, they were more inclined to disbelief than to faith, and what they said was not actually what was in their hearts. Allah knows the hypocrisy they hide in their hearts.
text.168:
The hypocrites did not participate in the war and said to their friends who had been killed in the Battle of Uhud, "If only they had followed us and stayed in Medina without participating in the war, they would not have died."

Say to them, O Muhammad, "Avert death from yourselves, if you are truthful." In reality, they will not be able to avert death even if they stay at home or take refuge in a strong fortress. At the appointed time, everyone will die. As for the causes of death, they may differ. Allah says:

"Wherever you may be, death will overtake you, even if you should be within fortified towers." (an-Nisa/4:78).
text.169:
Those who have been killed as martyrs in the path of Allah (fi sabilillah), do not think of them as dead, as the hypocrites assume, but they are alive with their Lord, receiving abundant sustenance and blessings.

Only Allah knows the exact nature of their continued existence. In a hadith narrated by Ibn Abbas, the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said:

"The martyrs are on the bank of a river near the gate of Paradise, they are in a green dome. Their sustenance comes out of Paradise every morning and evening." (Narrated by al-Hakim, Ahmad, and at-Tabarani from Ibn 'Abbas).

The martyrs enjoy the gifts of Allah, they wish to die as martyrs repeatedly. This is explained in the words of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him):

"No one who has died and obtained pleasure with Allah wishes to return to the world except the martyr. He wishes to be returned to the world, then be martyred again. That is because of the greatness of the virtue of martyrdom." (Narrated by Muslim)
text.170: After enjoying God's bounty, the martyrs of the Battle of Uhud said, "Hopefully our friends will know about this bliss." Then Allah answered, "I am the One who will convey this to them." The martyrs rejoiced at the grace and bounty that Allah had bestowed upon them. And they hoped that their comrades in arms who had not fallen in the path of Allah (fi sabilillah) would also obtain similar grace and blessings from Allah as they had obtained. For these, there is no fear and no sorrow.
text.171: The believers and mujahidin rejoice in the blessings from Allah as a reward for their deeds and for additional bounties. Indeed, Allah will not diminish the reward that has been determined for the believers and mujahidin.
text.172: The believers respond to the call of Allah and His Messenger to remain steadfast on the path of Allah even though they have suffered wounds. Those who do good and are righteous will receive a great reward.
text.173:
The revelation of this verse is related to Abu Sufyan, the commander of the Meccan polytheists and his army, who had returned from the Battle of Uhud. After reaching a place called Ruha, they regretted their actions and intended to return to continue the war. This news reached the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), so he summoned the Muslim troops to face Abu Sufyan and his army. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said, "Let none join the battle today except those who participated yesterday," while many of the Islamic soldiers at that time were wounded. But in the end, Allah (SWT) cast fear into the hearts of the polytheists, and they returned home.

The Mujahideen were intimidated by some enemies (hypocrites), who stated that the enemy had gathered new strength to face them. But the Mujahideen did not feel intimidated by this news; instead, their faith increased, and their enthusiasm to face the enemy of Allah increased with the words, "Allah is sufficient for us, and He is the best Disposer of affairs."
text.174: With that faith and strong determination, they were finally able to reach Medina. Abu Sufyan and his army did not end up launching an attack against them. They did not experience any suffering at all and remained in the pleasure of Allah.
text.175: The hypocritical enemies who try to frighten the believers are devils who invite their friends not to participate in battle and to frighten the Muslims by declaring that the enemy's numbers are very large and they have complete weapons. Allah warns that the *mujahidin* should not be influenced and should not follow them, but fear Allah and prepare to fight alongside the Messenger of Allah (saw) if you are truly believers.
text.176:
When the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) saw the condition of the Muslims during the Battle of Uhud, he felt sad and anxious. It was then that this verse was revealed to comfort the Prophet (peace be upon him), "O Muhammad, do not feel sad and anxious, seeing the actions of some of your hypocritical followers who, together with the disbelievers, gather all efforts and strength to defend disbelief. In reality, it is not you who they are fighting and oppressing, but Allah who they are fighting. Surely they will not be able to oppose Allah."

Their intention is to harm and bring detriment to the Muslims, but in reality, they themselves are the ones who will be harmed. Allah will not grant them forgiveness in the Hereafter. They will receive a painful and immeasurable punishment.
text.177: After Allah revealed the true nature of those who help and side with the disbelievers who oppose the Muslims, and affirmed that they are in reality opposing and fighting Allah, in this verse Allah explains that this also applies to everyone who prefers disbelief over faith. They do not harm Allah in the slightest, and for them is a painful punishment. They will not be able to do so, because Allah defends Islam. Rather, they will receive a severe punishment in the Hereafter.
text.178:
Let not the disbelievers ever think that the lengthening of their lives is good for themselves. It is not so, except if they were dignified and performed righteous deeds that would purify and cleanse them from vile things and bad characteristics.

Things like that would be beneficial for them and for other people. But in reality, they continue to commit disobedience and sins. Thus, they destroy themselves, so they receive a humiliating punishment.
text.179:
One of Allah's unchangeable laws (sunatullah) for His servants is that He will not leave the believers in a state of difficulty as they were during the Battle of Uhud. Allah will separate the believers from the hypocrites, improve the condition of the believers, and strengthen their faith. In difficult and trying circumstances, those with strong faith can be distinguished from those with weak faith. The Muslims are tested to what extent their faith and sincerity are in facing the disbelievers.

After the Muslims experienced difficulties in the Battle of Uhud because they were pushed back by the enemy, and they were almost discouraged, it was then known that among the Muslims were hypocrites who deviated and sided with the enemy. Those with weak faith became confused. In contrast, for those with strong faith, the difficulties they faced encouraged them to increase their faith and enthusiasm.

The unseen matters and hidden wisdom in this event are not shown except to certain people, such as the messengers chosen by Allah. Among the messengers, Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was chosen by Allah by giving him the privilege of knowing the contents of people's hearts, so that he could determine who among them truly believed and who was a hypocrite or disbeliever.

"He is the Knower of the unseen, and He does not disclose His unseen to anyone. Except to a messenger whom He has approved, and then He assigns watchers (angels) before him and behind him." (al-Jinn/72: 26-27).

After explaining the criticisms of the hypocrites against the prophethood of Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) after the Battle of Uhud and explaining that the event of Uhud contained many lessons (iktibar), the believers were commanded to remain faithful to Allah and His messengers, and to Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) who confirmed the previous messengers. If they believe in him, especially regarding unseen matters, and are mindful of Allah by avoiding His prohibitions and obeying all His commands, then they will receive a great reward.

In the Qur'an, the word "taqwa" (mindfulness of Allah) is often added after the word "iman" (faith), just as the word "zakat" (obligatory charity) is added after the word "salat" (prayer). This shows that faith is only complete if accompanied by taqwa, just as prayer is only complete if zakat is given.
text.180:
Those who have been given wealth and abundant blessings by Allah, then they are stingy, unwilling to fulfill their obligations regarding that wealth, such as zakat and others, are very reprehensible. Never think that stinginess is good and beneficial for them. Possessions and wealth will remain intact and not diminish if spent in the way of Allah; in fact, they will increase and be blessed. But stinginess is a bad thing and detrimental to themselves, because the wealth that is not spent will be hung around their necks on the Day of Judgment as a very severe punishment and torment, because the possessions that are hung around their necks will turn into snakes that tightly coil around them. Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) said:

"Whoever has been given wealth by Allah, then does not pay its zakat, his wealth will be shown to him in the form of a bald-headed snake with two black spots above its eyes, then it will be hung around his neck on the Day of Resurrection. The snake will open its jaws and say, 'I am your wealth, I am your treasure,' then the Prophet recited this verse." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and al-Nasai from Abu Hurairah).

Indeed, everything in the heavens and on earth belongs to Allah, given to whomever He wills as a trust and mandate. At any time, it can be withdrawn and transferred to the hands of others according to His will. So what is the reason for those who are stingy and unwilling to spend Allah's wealth to seek His pleasure? Whatever a person does, all of it is known by Allah and rewarded according to his deeds and intentions. Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) said:

"Verily, deeds are judged by intentions, and every person will have what he intended." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from 'Umar bin al-Khattab).
text.181:
When Allah's revelation descended:

"Who is it that will lend Allah a good loan..." (al-Baqarah/2:245), a Jew came to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) and said, "Is your Lord poor? Then He asks His servants to give Him loans? We are the rich ones." Then this verse was revealed. "Allah has certainly heard the statement of those [Jews] who said, "Indeed, Allah is poor, and we are rich." And believe that their words and their killing of the prophets without right will be recorded, then as a recompense, they will be given a fitting punishment. At that time, Allah will say to them, "Taste the punishment of the burning Fire, just as the followers of the Messenger felt the pain of your words in the world that pierced their feelings."
text.182:
The painful torment that befell them (the Jewish people) was a consequence of their own actions in the world. They said that Allah was poor. They killed prophets, committed wicked deeds, disobeyed, and so on.

Allah will never oppress His servants. Allah treats His servants according to their deeds. Allah says:

"Is there any reward for good other than good?" (ar-Rahman/55:60).

If their deeds are good, they will be rewarded with Paradise, and if their deeds are bad, they will be rewarded with Hell. Allah will not treat those who commit disobedience the same as those who are pious, just as the disbelievers are not the same as the believers.

"Or do those who commit evil deeds think We will make them like those who have believed and done righteous deeds - equal in their life and their death? Evil is that which they judge." (al-Jasiyah/45:21).
text.183:
Some Jews, including Kaab bin Asyraf, Malik bin as-saif, Finhas bin 'Azura and several others, came to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and said, "O Muhammad! You claim to be the Messenger of Allah and that Allah has revealed a Book to you, while in the Torah (Leviticus ix) we are forbidden by Allah to believe in a messenger unless he brings us a sacrifice that is consumed by fire. If you can prove that, then we will believe you." Then this verse was revealed. This is according to Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with him).

The admission of the Jews mentioned above is actually nonsense, because even if the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) proved it, they still would not believe. Their request was merely an excuse to not believe in the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). For that, Allah commanded the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to expose their lies with the words, "There came to you messengers before me, such as Zakaria, Yahya and others, bringing miracles that demonstrated the truth of their prophethood, and bringing what you proposed, such as bringing a sacrifice consumed by fire, which indeed has a special characteristic, namely burning. Therefore, in the past there was a belief that fire was always used as a benchmark to assess whether a sacrifice offered was accepted by God or not; if it burned, it meant it was accepted, but you still did not believe in them, and even killed them. So where is your truth? Try to prove it, if you are truly truthful."
text.184:
If they still persist in denying you, even after you have shown clear miracles and the Book that guides to the right path, then do not be upset or anxious about their hard-heartedness and disbelief.

Such a thing has also been experienced by the messengers before you. They were given what has been given to you, such as clear miracles. Allah brought *suhuf*, which are sheets containing revelations given to the prophets before you, the contents of which contained wisdom, and also brought the Book that provides perfect explanation, containing the laws of *sharia* such as the Torah, the Gospel (Injil), and the Psalms (Zabur). They remained patient and steadfast in the face of the hurtful actions of those who denied them.
text.185:
Every soul will taste death, and on the Day of Resurrection, each will be fully recompensed. The good will be rewarded with good, which is Paradise, and the bad will be rewarded with bad, which is Hell, in accordance with the words of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him):

"The grave is either a garden from the gardens of Paradise, or a pit from the pits of Hell." (Narrated by at-Tirmidhi and at-Tabarani).

Whoever is kept away from the Fire and admitted to Paradise, he is indeed successful. To achieve the happiness mentioned above, let us pay attention to the words of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) as follows:

"Whoever wishes to be kept away from the Fire and admitted to Paradise, let him die in a state of faith in Allah and the Last Day, and let him treat people as he would like to be treated by them." (Narrated by Imam Ahmad).

The life of this world is nothing but the enjoyment of delusion. The pleasures felt in this world, in the form of food, drink, rank, position, and so on, generally delude people. They think that is happiness, so they become immersed and engrossed in worldly pleasures. Whereas, if people are not wise in using them, these pleasures will become a disaster that causes loss in this world and will receive a painful torment in the Hereafter.
text.186:
In this verse, Allah explains that Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) and his followers will be tested as they were tested with difficulties in the Battle of Uhud. They will be tested again regarding their wealth and themselves. "You will surely be tested in your possessions and in yourselves." You will sacrifice your wealth to face your enemies in order to uphold the dignity of your community. You will increase your struggle, resulting in the loss of family, beloved comrades in arms, to defend the truth. You will be slandered by the People of the Book and those who associate partners with Allah. You will hear from them things that are hurtful, disturbing to the peace of mind, such as the slander of adultery launched by them against Siti Aisyah. She was left behind from the Prophet's (peace be upon him) group when returning from a battle, in a place because she was looking for her lost necklace, then Safwan bin Muattal came to pick her up. The hypocrites accused Aisyah of committing adultery with Safwan. A very shameful slander, and it shook the Medina community at that time, an event known as *hadisul ifki* (the false accusation).

So great was the slander launched and so many were the hurtful disturbances directed at you. But if you are patient in facing them and accept them with full piety, then all of that will have no meaning or influence at all, and indeed patience and piety are matters that must be prioritized.
text.187:
Allah took a covenant from those who were given the Scripture, namely the Jews and Christians, through their respective prophets, that they would explain the contents of the Scripture to mankind by clarifying the meanings contained within it, the background of its revelation, and that nothing would be concealed. But what happened?

They paid no attention whatsoever to those covenants; instead, they threw the covenant behind them, concealing the descriptions of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) that were clearly stated in their Scripture, namely Deuteronomy xviii.18: "I will raise up for them a prophet like you from among their brothers. And I will put my words in his mouth, and he shall speak to them all that I command him." These characteristics in the Old Testament are only found in Prophet Muhammad. Cf. John xv. 26 and xvi. 7 (see also as-Saff/61:6). They exchanged the eternal pleasure of Allah for a small price and value, namely a position that is not eternal and is destructive. How wrong and evil was the exchange they made.
text.188:
The characteristics of the Jews and Christians that believing Muslims must avoid are that they are always joyful about the deviations and betrayals they commit. They feel proud because they consider themselves to be community figures and leaders who are obeyed. They enjoy being praised for having a deep understanding of all the contents of the Book and being experts in interpreting it, even though they are not experts. They do this to divert the attention of the masses from the truth to what their leaders and the common people want, even if it is wrong.

Let not the Muslims think that the People of the Book whose actions are bad and deceptive will escape punishment; rather, they will feel a painful torment. Believers do not need to feel sad or anxious about their deviations, but should continue to explain the truth and never hide it in the slightest. Allah will fulfill what the Muslims desire and eliminate the evil things that have been forbidden.
text.189: The kingdom of the heavens and the earth is controlled by Allah, given to whomever He wills. Allah is All-Powerful over all things; it is not difficult for Him to grant help and victory to the Muslims over the People of the Book and the polytheists who harm them with their actions and words.
text.190:
It is narrated from Aisha r.a. that the Messenger of Allah saw said: "O Aisha, tonight I will worship Allah." Aisha r.a. replied, "Indeed, I am happy if the Messenger of Allah is beside me. I am happy to serve his wishes and desires." But alright! I have no objection. Then the Messenger of Allah saw got up from his bed, performed ablution, not far from his place, and then prayed.

While praying, he wept until his tears soaked his clothes, because he was contemplating the verses of the Qur'an that he was reciting. After praying, he sat down praising Allah and wept again, sobbing. Then he raised both his hands, prayed, and wept again, and his tears soaked the ground. After Bilal came to call the dawn prayer and saw the Prophet saw weeping, he asked, "O Messenger of Allah! Why are you weeping, even though Allah has forgiven your past and future sins?" The Prophet replied, "Am I not a servant who is worthy and deserving of being grateful to Allah? And how can I not weep? Tonight Allah has revealed a verse to me." Furthermore, he said, "How unfortunate and wretched are those who read this and do not think about and contemplate its meaning."

Thinking about the alternation of day and night, following the rising and setting of the sun, the day being longer than the night and vice versa. All of that shows the greatness and power of its Creator for those who have understanding. Thinking about the creation of the heavens and the earth, the regular alternation of day and night producing specific times for human life is a challenge in itself for believing intellectuals. They are expected to explain these natural phenomena academically, so that it can be concluded that God did not create all these phenomena in vain.
text.191:
One of the distinctive characteristics of people of understanding (Ulil Albab), which is a special trait of humans and this completeness is considered as a creature that has advantages over other creatures, is that when they pay attention to something, they always gain benefits and advantages. They always depict the greatness of Allah, remembering and commemorating the wisdom, virtue, and abundance of Allah's blessings upon them. They always remember Allah at all times and in all circumstances, whether they are standing, sitting, or lying down. No time or circumstance is allowed to pass by without being filled and used to think about the creation of the heavens and the earth. Thinking about the wonders contained within them, which illustrate the perfection of nature and the power of Allah.

By repeatedly contemplating these things deeply, in accordance with the saying of the Prophet saw, "Think and contemplate everything about Allah's creation, and never think and contemplate about the essence and nature of the Creator, because no matter what you do, you will not reach and will not be able to reach the essence of His Being."

Finally, every person of understanding will draw a conclusion and say, "Our Lord, You did not create all of this, namely the heavens and the earth and all that is in them, in vain, without a profound wisdom and a specific purpose that will make us happy in this world and in the hereafter. Glory be to You, O Allah, from all the unfounded suspicions directed at You, so protect us from the torment of the fire of hell that has been prepared for those who do not believe."

The creation of the heavens and the earth and the alternation of night and day are indeed very complex phenomena, which have continuously been the object of research for mankind since the beginning of human civilization.

In several surahs, including Surah al-Araf/7 verse 54, it is mentioned that the creation of the heavens and the earth took place in six periods (see also Scientific Study of Surah al-Araf/7:54).

The complexity of the creation of the heavens and the earth that took place in six periods has been explained by Dr. Achmad Marconi (see: Bagaimana Alam Semesta Diciptakan, Pendekatan al-Qur'an dan Sains Modern, Pustaka Jaya, 2003) as follows: The word *ayyam* is the plural form of *yaum*. The word *yaum* in everyday use is used to indicate the brightness of the day, interpreted as 'period'. While the plural form: *ayyam*, can mean 'several days' and can even mean 'a long time'. Seen from the use of the word *ayyam* in the verse above, it shows the relative nature of time by comparing human time with the time that applies to the movement of energy-matter in the universe. By Abdullah Yusuf Ali, (The Holy Qur'an, Text, Translation and Commentary, 1934), the word *yaum* (singular form of *ayyam*) is equated with the English word *age* or *aeon*. By Abdus Suud, a 16th-century commentator, the word *yaum* is equated with the understanding of "event" or *naubat*. It is more appropriate if the word *yaum* is translated as "stage" or period or era. Thus the phrase *fi sittati ayyam* in verse 54 of Surah al-Araf/7 above, is appropriate to be translated as 'in six periods'.

Marconi (2003) explains that these six periods are: First Period, From the 'Big Bang' from Singularity, until the separation of the Gravitational Force from the Single Force (Superforce), space-time began to separate. However, the Space-Time Continuum that was born was still vague, where the difference between energy-matter and space-time was unclear. Second Period, the mass of the formation of the inflation of the Universe, but the Universe is still not clear in shape, and is referred to as Cosmic Soup. The Strong-Nuclear Force separates from the Electro-Weak Force, and the fundamental materials begin to form: quarks, antiquarks, etc. The Universe begins to expand. Third Period, the period of formation of atomic nuclei in this Universe. The Weak-Nuclear Force begins to separate from the Electromagnetic Force. Atomic nuclei such as protons, neutrons, and mesons are composed of these quarks. This period is known as the period of formation of atomic nuclei (Nucleosyntheses). Space, time, matter and energy, begin to appear separate. Fourth Period, electrons begin to form, but are still in a free state, not yet bound by the atomic nucleus to form a stable atom. Fifth Period, the formation of stable atoms, the separation of matter and radiation, and the Universe, continues to expand and begins to appear transparent. Sixth Period, the Universe continues to expand, atoms begin to form aggregates into molecules, macro-molecules, then form proto-galaxies, galaxies, stars, solar systems, and planets.

Likewise, the alternation of night and day is a very complex phenomenon. This phenomenon involves 'the rotation of the earth (that is, the earth rotates on its axis), while 'revolving around the sun with the earth's axis tilted. In the phenomenon of physics, the earth precesses around the sun. So the alternation of night and day occurs because of the rotation of the earth that precesses around a star, namely the sun. Because its movement is tilted, the precession movement of the earth around the sun also has different seasonal impacts, depending on the position of the place on earth relative to the sun. In addition, the earth's rotation in precessing around the sun is stabilized by the moon that rotates around the earth, in astronomical terms, the moon provides rotational dynamic stability to the earth's rotation that precesses around the sun. Other planets that also revolve around the sun also provide rotational dynamic stability to the earth's precession towards the sun, Subhanallah! It is proven that the existence of the moon is very necessary for the precession of the earth on its axis to be stable. The moon provides stability in the time dimension of 10-100 years, while Venus and Mars provide stability in the time dimension of 100-500 years. Meanwhile, the planets Jupiter and Saturn also contribute to providing rotational dynamic stability to our earth, as well as acting as a shield for the earth against the scattering of meteors that will hit the earth (personal communication with Prof. Dr. Ir. Said D. Jenie, expert in Celestial Mechanics ITB) (see also Scientific Study of Surah al-Anam, verse 96).

Clearly, the phenomenon of Allah swt's creation is so complex regarding the 'Creation of the Heavens and the Earth, as well as the alternation of night and day. Only scientists and philosophers who are very excellent and diligent and *tawadhu* (humble), will be able to uncover the secrets of this nature. They are the ones referred to as *Ulil Albab* in the verse above. The creation of the Heavens and the Earth is very complex, and only 'a little is known to humans about it. The alternation of night is also very complex. In the modern era, science has been able to reveal that the moon, the planets Venus, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn, all have an influence in the form of rotational dynamic stability on the earth's rotation in precessing around the sun. They (the *ulil albab*) are the ones who come to the conclusion: "Our Lord, You did not create this in vain. Glory be to You, then protect us from the torment of hell".
text.192: O Allah, our Lord, we beseech You with utmost humility and reverence, that we may truly be kept far from the fire of Hell, the fire that will burn to ashes those who are arrogant and haughty in this world, those who refuse to accept the truth and righteousness that comes from You, the Creator of all the universe. We know that those whom You cast into Hell are those whom You have truly humiliated because of the injustice and disbelief they have committed in this world. They continuously feel the torment of Hell, because there is no helper for the unjust and disbelieving, who can deliver them from the pain of the torment they experience.
text.193:
After uttering a prayer based on contemplation and reflection on nature and all its wonders as mentioned above, it is followed by a prayer that illustrates attention to the call that was heard. O Allah, we have heard the call of Your Messenger, who called us to believe in You and to affirm Your word, so we immediately believed, carrying out all Your commands, avoiding all Your prohibitions, in accordance with the recommendations brought by Your Messenger.

Therefore, forgive the sins that we have committed and erase from us the minor sins that we have ever done, and let us die in a state of *husnul-khatimah*, together with the good people who do much good.
text.194:
Our Lord! We have carried out all Your commands. We always remember You at all times and in every circumstance. We have answered the call of Your Messenger. Therefore, O our Lord, grant us what You have promised through Your messengers. You have promised power in this world with Your word:

"Allah has promised those who have believed among you and done righteous deeds that He will surely grant them succession [to authority] upon the earth..." (an-Nur/24:55).

You have promised victory and help for those who are obedient and uphold Your religion, with Your word:

"...If you support Allah, He will support you..." (Muhammad/47:7).

Then in another verse, Allah says:

"Allah has promised the believing men and believing women gardens beneath which rivers flow..." (at-Taubah/9:72).

The things mentioned above are the happiness of this world and the hereafter that we greatly hope for, and do not ever disgrace us on the Day of Resurrection, in accordance with Your word:

"...On the Day when Allah will not disgrace the Prophet and those who believe with him..." (at-Tahrim/66:8).

All of this we ask with all humility, to strengthen our practice of all Your commands, because in this way we will obtain the happiness of this world and the hereafter, and not at all doubting Your promises, because we believe with full conviction that You will not break Your promise in the slightest.
text.195:
Ummi Salamah once said, "O Messenger of Allah! I have not heard Allah mention women at all concerning the hijrah." Then this verse was revealed. Due to their diligence in performing good deeds, filled with sincerity accompanied by earnest prayers, Allah granted their request.

It is explained that Allah will not waste the deeds of someone who is obedient and will not differentiate between men and women in giving rewards and recompense, because these two types are descended from one another, women come from men and vice versa. Therefore, whoever makes hijrah, whether male or female, is driven out of their homeland, is tortured because they are diligent in the path of Allah, fights the enemies of Allah and ultimately dies as a martyr, killed on the battlefield, Allah will surely erase all their mistakes, forgive their sins and will surely admit them into Paradise, as a reward and recompense from Him, as a realization of the prayer from the request that He granted. How fortunate they are, to receive rewards and recompense from Allah, because indeed the best reward and recompense is that which comes from Allah SWT.
text.196:
Although this verse is addressed to the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), it is also intended for his ummah (community), just as we see many verses that, according to their wording, are addressed to the Prophet (peace be upon him), but in reality are also addressed to all his followers. The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was never deceived by the enticements and deceptions of anyone during his lifetime, as narrated by Qatadah, who said, "By Allah, they never succeeded in deceiving the Prophet (peace be upon him) until he passed away."

From this verse, it can be understood that Muslims should not be deceived by the luxurious lives of the disbelievers whose sole purpose in life is to seek worldly wealth.

Muslims should be steadfast and patient in facing such things and continue to strive for happiness in this world and the hereafter, as Allah says:

"But seek, through that which Allah has bestowed upon you, the home of the Hereafter; and [yet], do not forget your share of the world. And do good as Allah has done good to you. And desire not corruption in the land. Indeed, Allah does not like corrupters." (al-Qasas/28:77).
text.197:
A believer does not need to worry, nor be discouraged by the luxury obtained by the disbelievers, the enemies of God, because such things are pleasures that are insignificant compared to the rewards and pleasures prepared for the believers in the hereafter. The Prophet Muhammad said:

"The comparison of life in this world to life in the hereafter is only like the finger of a person dipped into the sea." (Narrated by Muslim).

The water that clings to the finger, that is the world, and the seawater, that is the hereafter. Life in this world is only temporary, because they enjoy themselves only for as long as they live, then after they die, they will be placed in the worst of places.
text.198:
In contrast to the disbelievers who will be placed in hell, in the Hereafter, the righteous, those who practice the commands of Allah, and abandon all His prohibitions, will be placed in Paradise, to abide therein forever.

How fortunate they are, because what is with Allah is the best for those who are devoted. It is far better than the pleasures and luxuries that the disbelievers experience in the world, because they are limited, only lasting as long as life in this world. The Messenger of Allah gave a real example as conveyed by Umar bin al-Khattab r.a. who said:

"I visited the Messenger of Allah saw, at that time he was in a room, sleeping on a mat without bedding. Under his head was a pillow made of goatskin filled with fiber. At his feet were gathered tanning leaves. Above his head, a goatskin was hanging. I saw the marks of the mat on his two sides, so I wept. He said, "What makes you weep?" I replied, "O Messenger of Allah, Kisra and Caesar are always in pleasure, luxury and self-sufficiency, and you are the Messenger of Allah and in this condition?" The Messenger of Allah replied, "Are you not pleased that this world is for them and the Hereafter is for us?" (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim).
text.199:
Jabir bin Abdullah, Anas, Ibn Abbas, Qatadah, and al-Hasan said that this verse was revealed concerning an-Najashi, the king of Abyssinia who had converted to Islam when he died. The angel Jibril informed the Prophet saw, so the Prophet said to his companions, "Let us (perform the *salat gaib*) for an-Najashi." Some companions asked in astonishment, "Why are we ordered to pray for a *kafir* in the land of Abyssinia?" Then this verse was revealed.

Not all People of the Book deviate from the teachings of Allah, betray, or deny the truth brought by the Prophet Muhammad saw, but some of them, like an-Najashi, Abdullah bin Salam, and others, have a glorious history in their lives. They truly believe in Allah, believe in the Al-Qur'an revealed to the Messenger of Allah saw, as well as the heavenly books revealed to the prophets, they are obedient and humble to Allah, and do not exchange the verses of Allah for a small price, meaning they do not hide what they know about the coming of the Prophet Muhammad saw as a Messenger. They are good and upright People of the Book, whether they are Jews or Christians. They will receive a reward from their Lord as promised in His word:

They will be given a double reward for their perseverance, ¦. (al-Qasas/28:54)

Indeed, Allah is swift in reckoning because He knows everything clearly, both the reward He will give and the person who deserves to receive it.
text.200:
After discussing various wisdoms and laws since the beginning of this surah, in order to maintain and strengthen the implementation of these things, this surah (Ali 'Imran) is concluded with an encouragement for believers to be patient and steadfast in carrying out all of Allah's commands, overcoming all disturbances and trials, avoiding all His prohibitions, especially being patient and steadfast in facing opponents and enemies of the religion. Do not let the enemies of the religion be more patient and steadfast than us, so that victory is on their side. Believers should always be prepared in every way and effort, striving, facing possibilities that will diminish the authority, purity, and greatness of the Islamic religion. And as the essence, believers are encouraged to truly fear Allah with true *taqwa* wherever they are, because with the provision of *taqwa*, everything can be carried out well, blessed, and pleased by Allah swt.

Thus, whoever among the believers implements these 4 kinds of encouragements will surely attain victory and happiness, in this world and the hereafter.
